novel_text:
Colchester has a way of swallowing you. The Roman wall curls through the town like the rind of a fruit someone gnawed at and left on a plate, and if you walk its line twice in one day you start to feel the same jagged curve inside your head. I taught Latin and mathematics to teenagers in a terraced house off Magdalen Street, three afternoons a week and then as many evenings as I could stomach. The house was narrow, the ceiling flaked in corners, and the rain when it came drummed not on roof tiles but on the idea of roof tiles, a drum with the skin pulled too tight.

On Monday mornings the buses hissed past my window and a gull had taken to sitting on the telephone pole across the road. He kept one eye on me and the other on whatever gulls watch. He knew the schedule better than I did. He could sense bread, or failure, from streets away.

My name is Milo Seton. I have never liked the sound of it, but I imagine few of us do. A name is something given to you and then invited to stay the night for years on end. A tutor is something I chose to be because I was not strong enough to be anything else; you can hide behind the language of syllabi, the safety of markers and mocks, behind phrases like it depends and show your working. Students come to you with their fog and you make a show of living with it.

I was writing on the whiteboard with a blue pen that had run faint when the first hint of what I called later the Quiet Agreement came to me. Not a revelation, nothing with lightning. Something more like when a tight shirt finally gives at the seam.

Elliot, sixteen and scowling with his fringe over his eyes, was halfway through telling me that no one would ever use Latin in real life because it was dead, sir. It’s deader than dead. You're wasting your time, mate. He liked to call me mate when he wanted to be cruel and felt too young to be allowed. He’d brought in a packet of crisps and the smell of salt and vinegar caught in my throat.

"You will use it today," I said. Stupid reply. Teacherish. "Caveat emptor. When you buy your new trainers online and the picture lies to you. Caveat emptor, Elliot."

"I’m not buying anything," he said, which made no sense because I could see the tab open on his phone where he was trying to decide between two colours of shoes.

I drew, under the conjugation of amo, amas, amat, a crooked circle with four arrows inwards. "Pretend," I said, "that you and three others share a park. If you litter, the park becomes ugly. If you don't, the park stays clean. If the other three litter, your effort keeps only a quarter clean, but the others enjoy their laziness. So what happens?"

He rolled his eyes. "They litter."

"And you?"

He shrugged. "Depends what I feel like."

"There it is," I said, surprising myself at the way my finger tapped the whiteboard as if the board were a table and we were in a café in Rome. "There’s the whole of it. The shape of the bad decision. If every person chooses my benefit now over our benefit later, the park becomes a bin. But if each of us can be convinced—or compelled—to act for our benefit later at small cost now, then we win together. The trick has to be—"

"—to make it cool to clean up," he said, and then because he had made a joke that was not a joke, he smiled despite himself.

"Or to make it impossible to do otherwise," I said. "But compulsion fails when no one is looking. It always fails when you are tired. There must be a way that is neither morals nor police. There must be a third thing."

Elliot huffed and went back to his trainers. Marian, thirteen, on the other chair, picked at a thread on her cuff and asked when we would get to the Caesar translation. She liked the brutality of it; she had that expression a student gets when they hunt for a word the way you hunt for a lost earring under a sofa. Head tilted, one eye closed.

After they left, and the silence reset the room like the wake after a speedboat, I took a breath that did not land on the bottom of my lungs and wrote "Third Thing" on the board. You could see dust in the air that morning. It is a comforting lie that dust is skin: most of it is fabric, soil tracked in from the Abbey Field, pollen, Fibonacci spiral of fluff. Breathable history.

I stood back, as any man facing ridiculousness must stand back and pretend he is outside it. The clock on the chipped mantelpiece had stopped the week before and then restarted without permission two days later. It ticked in juddering seconds, as if remembering.

What I meant by the Quiet Agreement would take me ugly sentences and many nights to say. I pressed the cap back on the marker and it left a blue comet on the palm of my hand because the cap had cracked. I tasted vinegar still and thought of bins. And then: imagine the park is not a park but a river, not a river but a country, not a country but a planet, and each person has a button they can press each morning (work that hurts, an apology, passing the ball instead of shooting from distance) that costs them a point and gives everyone two tenths. How do you design a world where the button is pressed?

You are supposed to teach. I took off my glasses, rubbed the heel of my hand over my right eye until the black was still.

I had students through to six and then cooked an egg—which I burned—and watched the street. Someone had scrawled a rude word on the brick opposite two nights before and the Council had painted over it with paint that did not quite match. I have never understood why they do not keep some of the old paint when they repaint a row. The gull dropped down onto the black plastic bin and tried to peck through. The lid had been replaced by one of those sprung things that shuts like a mouth; the gull danced on it. A woman with a pink beanie walked by without seeing me at the window. Most people did, sometimes. My curtains were cheap, maybe that was it. Or the angle.

On Tuesdays I walked an extra thirty minutes to St Botolph’s Priory and sat on the broken wall with my coffee. Teenagers kissed under the archway where you can stand and hear your voice somehow larger than you are. Ancient stones make your mouth brave. A man in a high-vis vest practised a speech very softly and when he saw me noticing he folded the paper and whistled. The ruin was always colder than the air. I thought a great deal about colder things then.

It is ridiculous to put it like this, but I woke on that Wednesday with the sense that I had dreamt a lecture. In the dream there were twelve people and a white table, and I explained to them the conditions under which conflict ceases without force. The trick (if it could be called trick) was the simple possibility of mutual audit without humiliation. If you could see what other people refused to do, you could see what you must give them. It is dizzying on paper. As if the opposite of secrecy were not confession but practice.

By ten I had typed twelve pages. Words that felt like a sieve with water coming through. "The Quiet Agreement," the title sat there like a sapling that does not yet know wind. The meat of it was this: we are at war because our games are badly designed. We ask for promises that cannot be measured and we fall back to violence when we think someone smiles while breaking them. Instead, design the promise such that it is visible, nudgable, simple enough to score, and then remove punishment. Not because people are good. Because they are lazy, and this kind of lazy keeps the peace. Also because the cost of punishment is a war in miniature, every time. If we must waste energy, let it be in celebration not in the scaffolding of jails.

I did not tell anyone on the Wednesday. I printed the pages on a printer that thought paper was a rumor. It jammed and then ate a corner and spat ink. I left the copy on the mantelpiece under the clock that had stopped again.

On Thursday I told Ellie.

Not the teenager. Ellie upstairs. We had never decided if we were friends, and so we had avoided the word. She was twenty-nine and had bought the top floor from a previous landlord when I thought no one my age would ever own anything again. Her hair was the colour of hazelnuts in rain, which is a sentence I should burn for writing. She came down sometimes when she heard me playing Schubert too loud—badly—and knocked as if we were both tenants in a truce.

"Soup," she said when I opened the door. "I’ve made too much. Carrot also ginger. Do not argue." She wore an old band T-shirt and had drawn cat whiskers on the inside of her wrist in pen, a childish tattoo practice.

"Thank you," I said, and remembered to step back. People waited sometimes, on the threshold, as if my hallway were narrower than it was. "Do you have a minute? I have done something foolish."

"When haven’t you," she said. She walked in and stood in front of the whiteboard. "Oh lord, Latin. Save me from endings. Milo, what’s the square for? Third thing? You joined a cult?"

I held up the sheaf of paper and she took it and leafed through. Her eyes moved fast, but it was not the fast of comprehension, it was the fast of looking for something to laugh at and then not finding it. She reached the page where I wrote about the shape of apologies that repair and those that marinate the wound instead, and her teeth clicked together. She did that when she was thinking; I had heard it through the floorboards. I had lived with that little ice of sound long enough that I knew when she would make it and when not.

"This is… not nonsense," she said. "It is something. Do not be offended. You have a talent for building scaffolding and then not letting the builders in. But this is something."

"It is naive," I said.

"Yes. But clever naive is different to stupid naive. How do you make governments read it?"

"You don’t," I said. "You let it go loose and hope people talk and it infects something. Or you throw it in the river and in twenty years someone else writes it better and you clap without saying anything."

"I could show my brother," she said. "He works in community—" She stopped. I saw the moment she decided no. People guard their siblings as if they were their first pets. "No. Not yet. Do you put it online?"

"I hate online," I said. The word tasted like plastic.

"Then you will hate this less because it is yours," she said, and gave me her soup and said my saucepans were too clean and left.

I pressed publish on Friday afternoon. There is a small sound one’s laptop makes, the faint delay between the click and the turning of wheels somewhere else. It feels like posting a letter in a wall and waiting to hear something breathe behind it.

Then the days had more people in them. Not in my flat but in my screens and the street outside. My email did the flood. People who did not know me called me a fool. People who thought they knew me better than they did called me a saint. It is very easy on the internet to give a stranger a halo made of someone else’s spite.

Local reaction was the oddest. I'd expected to be ignored in the neighbourhood because that is what small cities do best—ignore noisily. Instead, two women at the Co-op said "you’re him, aren’t you?" and then as if that were something they had meant to say on purpose, one of them touched my forearm with two fingers and said "brave." I had not been brave and no part of me wanted to be brave now.

At The Old Siege House, the barman refused to take my five-pound note and said, "It’s on the house if you can tell me how to make Carl stop smashing glasses when West Ham lose." Laughter. I told him to hang a heavy bag in the cellar and give Carl three minutes. Carl looked at me from the other end and his left eye did something I had not seen an eye do, which made me think he had been hit there once. He raised his pint. It was not an acceptance.

A man from the Council who had never met me sent an email with a PDF attached. The file asked me to attend a conversation about civic responsibility and new ideas. It was written in a voicing that gave me a headache. I said yes. There are times when no is a kettle whistling that no one hears.

For balance the choir of ordinary disapproval filled itself in. A tutor, really? Who does he think he is? Latin? What has that got to do with anything? Peace is not a spreadsheet, you grammar clown. An old headmaster I liked wrote me a private message to say, in the kindest way anyone can say such a thing, that I had given ammunition to the type of person who would use my argument to make people make sacrifices for things they would never benefit from. That my third thing could become a cover for old first things. That, in short, I had not invented a windproof umbrella but a new name for rain.

On Sunday my neighbour announced he had bought a castle.

I had not, before that lunchtime, thought of him as a neighbour. He had lived across the landing for a month, shifting boxes that looked as if ships had brought them. His name, he’d said in the stairwell once, was Rafe. Rafe what? Alder? Elgar? He said it quickly and I did not catch it, and then too many days had passed for me to ask again. He had a way of standing that suggested he had once been taller and had been folded at the sternum for storage.

He knocked and I opened and he said, directly, like a man refusing to pass on the message to a messenger, "I have bought a castle and I would like to know if you want to see it before it falls down."

"Yesterday I posted an essay that appears to be trying to make peace with the world," I said. "And today you say you have bought a castle. There is no ordinary day anymore, is there."

"Was there before?" he said, and walked in without waiting, and then seemed to remember something because he turned and stepped back out again, as if he had crossed the wrong threshold in a game. "I did knock," he said from the hall.

"You did," I said.

"A ruin at Blackmere," he said. "East, toward Ardleigh. Do you know it?"

I did not. He told me it was a keep of four storeys built with stone that never came near this part of Essex except when men wanted to prove something. It had been a folly of a late lord and then near enough to a real ruin to attract teenagers with beer.

"Derelict," he said, pronouncing every letter. "Deralict if you’re writing the sign to put them off. There’s bracken growing through the cracks and an owl that has made the stair its own place to be. I have bought it. I have no money left."

"Why," I said. I should have said congratulations, but you must forgive me for wanting to know why first. "Why do that."

He turned the words in his mouth before letting them out. "Because I am tired of this—" he gestured and his hand took in my whiteboard, the refrigerator magnets, the little plant that had turned its leaves to the wall and died without the decency to be obvious about it—"being the whole picture. Because our town is layered and I want the layer that insists. Because you wrote something yesterday that reminded me of a man I knew who once said that a wall is a promise, and promises must be either kept or allowed to fall. I thought—well. I’ll keep one then. Can you drive?"

"I can," I said. "I have not, in a while."

"You will," he said, "and I will sit beside you and tell you which roads still exist."

He had the keys in his pocket. They looked like the sort of keys a child draws when asked to draw keys. He had grown a beard that did not match him.

We drove after four, when the light was angrily yellow at the edges. The lanes out beyond the Hythe are designed for one-and-a-half cars, and you become the decimals. Hedges like sentences that someone had not finished. Rafe pointed at farms and named them. "Past there the Boden boy was knocked off his bike. There, the best plums when the woman who owns the tree goes inside for her tea. There, my mother’s friend used to pick blackberries until she met a man with a dog that didn’t bark and decided that hedges are not fate." He said all this without making it sound like the sort of local knowledge that is meant to impress.

"How did you buy a castle?" I said. "Isn’t that the sort of thing a duke stops you doing?"

"The duke would rather a man like me own it than a company that will make it a theme park," he said. "Also, I wrote him a letter saying I would not call it a castle. It never was. A keep only. Castle is for tourists; keep is the thing you do."

"And what is the thing you do?"

"Keep," he said.

We turned down a track and the car’s undercarriage sighed. The ruin appeared not at once but in sneaky assemblies: a tooth of stone here, a patch of overgrown field that revealed itself as a courtyard only when you stepped into it. The owl lifted like a question mark and vanished into the darker question of the stairwell.

Rafe waited at the outer wall while I walked forward. There was a narrow window slit at about the height of my shoulder. You imagine men peering through, but never think about the mundane moments when they were bored and flicked small pebbles and shaved the ends of sticks and asked the same old questions about meat and mothers and whether it would snow. I pressed my palm against the stone and it answered with a coldness that unpacked my entire arm. I had never felt that exact degree of cold before. I pulled back, and then, because the part of me that keeps promises yelled it louder, I put my hand to it again.

"What is it," Rafe called.

"It's—" I started. The word failed to choose a vowel. It's nothing. It's sandstone. It's the same stuff they use in town. "Older than I am," I said finally and uselessly.

"Everything is," he said, and came inside and showed me the crack in the north wall that made an angle you could not draw; it refused a square. "Surveyors come on Monday," he said. "He will tell me to put steel in it. I will pretend to cry and then I will do it because I am not romantic enough to let it fall."

"You said you have no money left."

"I have friends," he said. "And I have things I do not need. Let me tell you about the man who only owned one chair in each room. He never had to think about where to sit."

We climbed the stair. On the second turn there was a draft that did not fit with the architecture; air can be a liar too. When we reached the second landing, I saw what he had meant by owl. White curls of feather like someone had exhaled chalk. The floor was uncertain and I did not step further, not because I was afraid of falling. Falling is a moment with an idea in it. I was afraid of something else. A silence that was not absence but observation.

"People will be angry," I said, and I hadn't meant to speak it but there it was, out.

"Because I bought this?"

"No. Because I wrote something and strangers think that if I must be wrong—" I could not find the nouns, which made me angry at an abstract that did not help. "Because they have had their fights too long and they do not want the shape of them to change. Because your keep and my essay have in common a small practical mysticism and there is nothing people mock more easily than a mystic with a plan."

"They mocked Brunel," Rafe said.

"And he built bridges with iron. I have built something with grammar," I said.

"You underestimate grammar," he said. "It is the lever we put on thought." He put his hand to the wall as I had, and did not flinch. The owl let us be. The wind made a throat in the doorway and worried at it.

We stood a long time in a ruin that had been designed for men to feel taller than they were, and for a moment I did feel taller. Like the inside of me had been reset to a measurement not taken from other people’s faces.

When we left I looked back and saw the outline of the keep against the dark trees and the evening startled me; I had not expected it to be so quick, as if someone had put their thumb on the sky and smudged it. Rafe locked the fat padlock and patted the door in a ridiculous way, as if he were excusing himself from a conversation with a person who would hold grudges.

"Thank you for bringing me," I said when we were back at the car. "People will use your keep as a pretext for romance."

"They will get their trousers muddy," he said. "Romance in England is always mud mixed with longing." He turned and looked at me then in a way he had not looked at me before, as if measuring. "You wrote about peace as if it were a muscle everyone had and forgot. I am good at remembering other people’s muscles. Maybe that is what this will be. An exercise."

"Do not use my metaphors against me," I said.

At home that night the clock did not so much start as remember it had once known time and grudgingly imitate it. I made tea and then did not drink it. I wrote a reply to a professor in Glasgow who had written to tell me I had reinvented his paper from 2004 with more adjectives. I opened a message from someone called Nadia who said simply that if I was right then she would forgive her father on Friday. I closed that message and opened it again twice.

I slept badly. The dream returned, the white table, the twelve people, but now there were only eleven. One chair was empty and the chair shone with that glossy varnish emptiness has when it wants you to talk about it.

In the morning someone had scrawled "shut up milo" on the wall opposite in pen. The Council had not yet had time to paint over it. An ex-boyfriend would recognize your flaws in the writing of strangers. The gull did not come to the pole. The bus was late.

The Council meeting—conversation; they had refused to call it a panel—took place in a room that felt like the inside of a filing cabinet. People had bring-your-own water bottles and highlighters colour-coded for topics. A woman with a crisp scarf said, "we are excited to explore new paradigms," and I was already asleep where the part of me that has to guard itself sleeps. That part is never fully awake anyway.

"We cannot," said a man from the police, "base community relations on mutual audit without any recourse to sanction. There must be an answer to the man who does not care."

"Then you build a system which makes it cheap to care," I said. "The sanction is exile from the rituals he wants. You turn ceremony into its own currency."

"But who runs it," said another, and she meant, who middles it, who gets the fees and the power.

"Someone invisible," I said, and immediately realized I had said the one phrase guaranteed to lose a room.

"God?" someone snorted.

"Not a god," I said. "Not a father either. The invisible is not higher. It is closer. You make small groups who copy rituals locally. You never let it become an office." I tried to explain that the thing that keeps peace is not the fear of punishment but habit, and the thing that keeps habit is not boredom but belonging, and that you could ratchet belonging very gently with public, measurable, undignified little points like stamps on a coffee card, and that you could stack a town with them until a fight felt like a waste of time. I tried. I tried and trailed, as we all do when the room is colder than your tongue.

After, a woman with very large glasses juggled a baby on her hip and said, "I liked your paper, Mr Seton," and looked at me as if I had time to be a young man. "People will call you utopian when they mean cruel. Be careful."

"Are you ever careful," I said, because I did not know what else to do with a kindness.

She laughed. "No. But I am not useful; you are trying to be."

At the tram stop—or what passes for a tram stop when you have no trams and only a patch of pavement where the idea of a tram might one day set its foot—an old man in a red jumper said, "you’re the one. They will stop buying you tea when the next thing happens," and I nodded because he was almost certainly right. His dog sniffed my shoe and licked air three inches from my ankle.

The world has a way of humming just before a shock. Mine hummed. It could have been the fridge dying again. It could have been the traffic. It could have been the Lamentations choral Ellie played upstairs on Saturday mornings when she cleaned. On Thursday night—not the night of the Council, the week after—I came home to find my window cracked from edge to edge by a stone that had failed to make an entrance. The words on the opposite wall had been painted over with thick, wrong colour. The quiet inside the house had a rusty edge. I thought of the ruin at Blackmere and of the smell of damp stone that is older than the word England.

I made a list of the names of my students and next to each wrote something tender. Marian: hoards pain like a squirrel and then surprises herself by laughing. Elliot: has a joke ready even when tired. Keisha: sees patterns in numbers that are not on the page but are there if you are brave enough. It felt like counting kings.

At ten, a knock. I assumed Rafe because no one else knocked like that—four taps in a sequence that was almost music. It was not. It was a man with a shaved head I had seen outside the Siege House and two boys who were too large to be called boys and too young to be called men. They had come to tell me I was wrong. Not in so many words. "I read your thing," the shaved-head man said. "You reckon I should do more and get less. That’s not happening."

"It is not doing more and getting less," I said, acutely aware of the way my voice becomes a lecture when frightened, as if formality could deflect cheap violence. "It is doing something that keeps the roof on, and you get more of the thing you cannot count."

"What’s that, then," he said. Behind him one of the boys shifted and his trainer squeaked on the tile like a cicada.

"Peace," I said, and could have laughed at myself but did not.

He rolled the word in his mouth and you could see him disliking the taste because it was not a taste he could compare to anything. "Peace is when no one looks at you," he said. "We don’t have that where I come from."

"Where do you come from," I said.

He named Essex. We all come from somewhere even when it is the place we are. He poked my chest with his finger, and I did not move, not out of bravery but because moving might have admitted something I did not want to admit—that I was warmer or cooler or present in a way I did not know. He nodded, as if his finger had met less resistance than expected. He frowned. His eyes went unfocused for a second at the exact point where they should have been focused, and then he stepped back and swore softly.

"You see," he said to the boy on his left, "he's not even—" He left the sentence unopened, like a letter returned to the sender.

"Leave it," the boy said. "Come on."

They went. They had delivered their soft threat and collected their confusion, which I had not intended to give them and would not have been able to give back if I had. I shut the door gently, which is how you shut a door when you want it not to notice it has been used.

I stood in the hall and put my hand flat on the wood of the door and felt the warmth of the room on one side and the cold of the hall on the other. Warmth, cold. You are supposed to feel both. That night I wrote another page and in it I confessed, to myself, that a good idea is not necessarily a safe one. I did not publish that part. I am not brave, I have said this, and yet I went back to Blackmere with Rafe on the Saturday with a blanket and a thermos and a new and stupid faith in walls.

We took the long way through the fields, and at one point, as I stepped over a low fence, my shoe did not catch on the top wire when it should have. The fence should have hummed because the farmer had strung it and left the battery on, but it did not. The details are small: a feather does not touch the surface of your skin; a child runs past you and you rearrange yourself to let the child pass and find you did not need to; you cough at night and the cough is a motion without resistance. You ignore such things because you are busy and appetite is a great liar in this.

"Do you hear that," Rafe said, and I did not. Perhaps I did and did not know I did.

"The owl?"

"Something like a rope singing," he said. "Never mind." He had brought a hammer without nails because men like to carry hammers, I have noticed. He used it to knock a loose bit of flint back into its place in the outer wall, and the wall took it as a child takes a toy given back. I laughed. He asked me to tell him what had happened with the men who had come to test their anger against my door. I told him and he made a shape with his mouth like he was going to call me a fool and then did not.

"We are not built for everyone knowing us," he said when we were at the top, looking out. "Even people in villages did not really know each other. They knew names and routines. Now a man in Leeds can decide you are his problem before breakfast."

"You have still bought a keep," I said.

"I have," he said. "And because of that, when the man in Leeds is angry he will at least have a place, in his head, to put that anger down. He can imagine this square of stone and realize it is not his. That helps."

"Does it," I said.

"It does me," he said.

The month turned over. The Council painted the wall correctly this time. The gull left and a smaller one took its place, a quieter apprentice gull. Ellie came down and told me her brother had read my paper and had sent a message that he was proud, and that he had laughed at one of my lines and that I was not funny. She kissed my cheek, startling both of us. She said it was for luck and immediately did it again on the other side in case the first had cursed me. People in Colchester do not often kiss neighbours unless the world is in a peculiar mood. It was.

If there is such a thing as a chapter in a life you do not know you are writing, then this is where the next one would begin: with me standing in a room that had a clock I did not trust, holding a letter I did not open as fast as I should have, hearing a sound from across the landing that might have been Rafe dropping something and might have been something else entirely. In the letter a university asked me to speak—how does one speak?—about my Quiet Agreement at a conference on design. People had misfiled me under designers, which did not feel wrong. It did not feel right either.

Here is an oddity. I began to realise that the house did not make the sounds I expected houses to make. Pipes never banged. The fridge hummed only when I mentioned it. The doorbell was rung and I did not hear it; I heard the knock instead. In the street, sometimes, someone would call a name and the name would skip me like a stone skipping water. I have looked for these sentences in my notebooks: the first time I wrote down that I had to move a chair not because it was in my way but because I wanted it to be. A chair in the corner collected dust thick enough to be pressed with a finger, and yet my fingers did not mark it. When I drank tea, the steam was for the room.

These are the sorts of things I think about now. They were then, in those weeks, a background only. Peace, castle, neighbour, letters, gull. If you had asked me what my life was then, I would have told you the story about Elliot confessing he'd cheated on a past paper and asking if that made him a bad person, and me telling him that on the contrary, the confession and not the cheating was the moral act and then sending him to make it to his mother. Or the story about Rafe finding a fox asleep in the ash on the lowest floor of the keep and standing so still the animal woke, noticed, and decided he was a part of the ruin. Or the story about Ellie downstairs, abandoning her soup on the step because her phone told her her father was in hospital and she could not hold both the soup and the phone and her own breath and she chose breath and I found the soup gone cold later and warmed it and left it upstairs by her door without a note.

These are the stories you think you are living in, until one morning at half past five you step out into the hall because you have heard something break, and you put your foot down, and you do not feel the floor. You see it. You see the grain in the wood and the small piece of grit that a builder left there in 1987 and the way the light from the street comes in from under the door like fog. But your foot does not find the wood in the way a foot finds the wooden thing which is a floor.

I did not fall. That is the strange mercy. I did not fall because there was nothing to fall from and nothing to fall to. I withdrew, if that is the word. A snail going back to safer geometry.

I stood with my hand on the wall and the wall coolly ignored me. The house took a breath around me and let it out and I did not smell the exhale.

I went to Blackmere that afternoon and the owl was waiting at the second turn of the stair, as if it had been given my appointment, and it stared as if I were not the sort of thing that moves. Rafe came a minute later and put his hand on my shoulder to jolt me—an affectionate battery—and his hand hovered and then landed in a different way, and he took it back with the same speed with which you pull your hand back from hot iron. He stared. I stared back. Neither of us said anything then; we are both, if nothing else, men who can leave a sentence unfinished when it will do more harm with its last words.

He said instead, looking down the well of the stair, "They have been drinking here again. There are bottles. I will write my sign with deralict spelled wrong on purpose. That sometimes keeps them away. Their teachers will come up and correct it and feel moral and forget to climb quite this high." He kept his eyes away from mine, and I loved him, in the little way we love our neighbours when they refuse our disasters as if refusing implies we are still afforded privacy.

"Do you know," he said because he could not carry the silence any longer, "when I was a boy, my father told me that when you walk along the old wall in town you must not step on the old stones and the new stones in the same pace because the rhythm annoys the dead. I have walked in that jag ever since. My knees hate me now. But I do it anyway. We build our peace on strange assumptions."

"And it holds," I said.

"It holds," he said, and then he said my name softly and I did not answer. He said it again and this time I did, and in the space between name and answer there was a thing neither of us could enter and neither of us wanted to name. We are practical men, even when we are impractical.

When we returned to town, Ellie caught me at the bottom of the stairs and said "I have been offered a job in London," and asked me if that meant she had to stop paying me for our arrangement whereby I tutored her nephew over video calls. "I suppose not," she said, and I nodded and she leaned as if she would touch my arm and then, remembering something or perhaps only noticing a fly, pulled back and smiled in that sweet way that pretends nothing has been stopped in its track. She asked if I would come up for a drink to celebrate and I said yes and then stood in my room while upstairs she poured wine and called down and I did not move and I did not know if I would be able to climb the stairs. The house smelled like dust and soup and music—distant, someone’s radio through two walls. I did not smell it. That is not the same as saying it was not there. But to me, it was a tune behind glass.

Peace, I thought, is a room you can always get back to. It is a room the door to which does not become a wall. Rafe has bought himself a wall to keep. I have written myself a door. My hand on the handle did nothing. I stood, and in my mind I opened a page and wrote at the top: conditions under which a man might be dead without noticing. Underneath that I did not write anything at all. Not then. Not yet. Not until the keep at Blackmere had a scaffold on its north side and the owl moved its nest because men had come and made the air vertical and given it a map of how to move around us. Not until the gull returned to the pole, older now, with a darker opinion of chips.

If I have a flaw—and I have ten—then one of them is the belief that if I explain a thing carefully enough it will become gentle. You cannot explain a ruin. You cannot explain a deralict—yes, I will spell it that way now and then, as if the wrongness were the point—stone into safety. You cannot explain the way a friend’s hand hovers because something in your shoulder is only partly of this place. You cannot explain to a boy with two trainers to choose that the choosing matters less than the small shame of lying about it to yourself. You live it. You live it in four rooms and a ruin and a town that was built by men who thought their walls would outlast everyone else, and you answer the door when men come to tell you you are wrong, and you are wrong, and you are right, and your name, when it is spoken kindly, still feels like a thing you are borrowing. You live it until even the quiet is a kind of speaking, and the wall opposite is painted over in the correct shade, and the world decides whether to let you keep the secret you thought was yours. You live it through, which is another kind of keeping. And you keep going to the keep, of course. You keep. You keep. You keep.In the morning I boiled water and only knew it was boiling because the kettle said so. The sound had that granular urgency, but the steam rose without claiming me, and when I held my hand above the spout there was a theatre of whiteness and no heat where heat should have been. I made toast and buttered it and the butter was a behaviour: it yielded, it slipped, it left its gloss; the taste in my mouth was memory with the edges knocked off. I put a mug on the table and pushed it, and it did not slide; the table still believed in friction even if my skin did not. I lifted the mug and stopped halfway, not from weight but from the absence of it; there is something in lifting that is the resistance itself, and without that minute wrestling the gesture becomes pantomime. I do not recommend becoming the backdrop to your own house. You begin to give the furniture the benefit of the doubt.

I told myself that routine is an argument you make with the world until it sighs and lets you be, so I set out the books for the eleven o’clock and stood by the whiteboard and wrote the date and found the pen moved as if guided by a spider in the corner. The ink laid itself down where I thought I was pressing, and when I was done my palm had no comet this time. Marian arrived early and stood with her rucksack still on and said, without greeting, "He didn’t read it," and I knew from the way she held her mouth that she meant her father and that the sacred text had been a message she had crafted with commas in the right places and put under his door. "He was drunk," she added, not because I needed that extra syllable but because she did. I did not reach out; I lack that kind of reach in the best of weeks and this was not that. Instead I said, "We can make Caesar bloody for you," and she shook her head and said, "No, not today," and we conjugated verbs like a spell to keep a house from falling.

Elliot was late and came in smelling of deodorant deployed as a disguise for sleep. He took one look at me and said, "You look weird," and then because he had reached that age where he could detect something frightening in himself and slap it with a joke, he added, "Like you’ve seen a ghost who told you to moisturise." I laughed because it was a good line and because he needed me to prove I was still there enough to laugh at him. We went through subjunctives and he told me with a theatrical groan that if he were a better person he would do his homework, and Marian, with a precise cruelty born of tiredness, corrected him: "If you were a better person, you’d do your homework." They bickered and I stood between their grammar as if I were a banister. Halfway through, as Elliot leaned to scribble something on the board, his shoulder brushed my sleeve and he pulled back instinctively, then pretended he had tripped on the chair leg. We agreed, silently, on the lie because it was kind.

When they had gone, Ellie leaned over the banister from the first landing and dangled a glass of wine like a fishing lure. "I’m practising for all the people in London who are going to ask me to celebrate their news by making them carry their own glasses," she said. "Come up. The song is good." From above came a throb of something with a cello in it, long notes that would have been self-pity if they had not been honest. I stood on the first step and then on the second and felt the grain of the wood with my eyes. There is an art to failing to walk without letting your friend feel accused by it. I thought of the way a cat will stop on a threshold and pretend to have noticed a moth you cannot see. "Give me a minute," I said, and sat down on the step with more ceremony than necessary. Ellie came down two steps and sat too, as if this had been her plan all along. We drank on the stairs like students who had failed to move house. She told me she had said yes to the job, a role with a title that had words like strategy and stakeholder perched uncomfortably on it, and I told her I would miss the way her Lamentations came through the ceiling like the polite crying of a stranger. She bumped her shoulder very gently against mine, an air-shoulder, a pantomime of contact so well performed that, for a moment, it felt warmer than anything else.

"You’re scaring me a little," she said eventually. "Not because of the paper. Because you look like you’re working hard to be here. I don’t mean here as in me and my terrible band T-shirts. I mean here-the-noun." I tasted the wine then, a late bloom, and found it like fruit in a memory. "I may be working too hard," I said. "It’s a season. Maybe it’s someone else’s season and I’m standing in the wrong field." She made her thinking-teeth click. "If you’re becoming a ghost, would you warn me? I have a horror of haunted kitchens." The joke was an umbrella for both of us. We sat until the song ended and she took the glass back and went upstairs and I went down and the house decided to hum again for a while in a way that suggested machines in other rooms, other flats, living. You can be grateful for your neighbours’ boilers.

Rafe called after lunch, the kind of call you answer even if you pretend you have not looked at your phone all day because the man himself vibrates in a different frequency. "They’ve put up the first pole," he said over a wind that had opinions. "You should come and tell me if I am being a coward about the north crack or giving myself a future." He did not ask if I could drive; he had decided I could. The lane out past the Hythe had remembered rain in the night and gave it back to our tyres in a thin song. His hammer lay on the passenger-side footwell and hit my ankle twice when we took a corner too keenly. "There will be a point," he said as we pulled in over nettles that had declared themselves sovereign, "to a line of ribbon." He had arrived at his own religion of tokens without reading mine; his sister, if he had one, would have kept him from my draft. "Picture this: anyone who spends an hour picking glass and bracken gets a strip of cloth—blue for hours, red for tools, white for making someone else tea—and we tie them along the entry arch. No names. No prizes. Just colour. The next time a boy comes with a can he sees not the rules about deraliction but the record of doing. Maybe he ties his own ribbon because it is a thing his hands can confess to."

"It’s pomp," I said, which is not an insult in England. "It’s habit with a better hat. The audit is visible to anyone who needs to take heart from it and invisible to those who come to mock." He grinned and the wind licked the grin away. "I stole it from the sea," he said. "All those little flags saying ‘we are doing our job’ as if the job were waving. Come on, help me decide where to put the first knot so it looks like we always meant it to be there."

We tied the first blue ribbon at shoulder height and the breeze immediately began its work, turning measurement into dance. He had a box of scraps that had once been shirts and curtains and a tablecloth that had lived through a dozen roast chickens; the keep would wear our domestic lives as war decorations. I thought of my paper on the mantel and how it asked for systems without humiliation, and here was one. You could be seen without your face being taken. He drafted three teenagers with bikes into the tying by offering them a go with the hammer on the flint, a swap of dignities, and by the time we had wrapped enough colour to make the arch mouth like a carnival, one of them had confessed that his friends would come drink there tonight and that he would try to stop them because he wanted to see what would happen to the ribbons. "If they burn them," he said with the tightness of someone recognising his own future meanness, "will you put more up?" Rafe said, "Every day until we tire of ourselves," and the boy nodded as if in relief; people like to hear that adults are prepared to repeat themselves for a cause that is not money.

The rope sang that afternoon. It was the guys from the scaffold team dragging a coil round the outer face and the fibres taking the sky into their throat. I stood under it and felt, not the vibration itself, but the idea of it. Sound becomes an outline when you cannot get your fingers into it. The foreman, a square of a man with a face like a wind-polished fence post, told me, "We’re going to baby it," and I nodded and resisted the urge to ask if we could baby me as well. The owl watched from a darker shelf and, for the first time, allowed itself a sound: a low vowel emptied of consonants. If I were fanciful I would say it had an opinion about ribbons.

At home there were two letters under the door. One was from the university with paper heavy enough to bruise; they wished to fly me to a design conference in Eindhoven and pay for a hotel with a lobby that would make me feel underdressed. I held the letter for a while in my hand and then put it down and did not lift it again for an hour. The other letter was from Nadia, the woman who had promised to forgive her father on Friday if I were right. She wrote in a hand that made every l look like the start of a different word. "I did it," she wrote. "He cried first. I think we both hated it a little. Then we ate chicken and watched football and were bored together and it was like discovering a room in a house I had lived in for ten years. Not a new room. One we had ignored. You know what I mean. I don’t think you’re right. But you’re useful." I put the letter under the clock and hoped for a tick that would make it more true. The clock did not indulge me.

There is a class of kindness that feels like a tax, and the Council sent me an email that wore that hat. They had begun, they said, a pilot of my very ideas—only they were careful to say ideas like mine—and would I like to observe from a position of absolute lack of authority and significant responsibility. They were going to place a small board near the bus station on Queen Street where people could record the number of times they had moved a bin back into place or held a door or kept a queue civil when no one was paid to shepherd it. You could press a button with your elbow or your knuckle and a tally would rise, and once a week someone would chalk the numbers on a slate and hang it high, out of reach. "We will not celebrate or shame," the email said, and then, with a sighing inevitability, "we will hold a small celebration if the numbers rise." I said yes to the observing and no to the celebrating and then immediately sent them a list of ways they could turn celebration into a proof of concept without cake. They ignored my list and ordered cupcakes with green icing and the word together in sugar.

My reflection and I had a conversation in the bathroom that would have stopped a stranger in the street: one of us had the correct number of bones. The glass tried its best; it caught me faithfully from the nose up and then lost heart. When I leaned close I could see the skin at the side of my eye tired in a way that made me forgive alarm clocks. At the optician, where I went under the pretext of a loosening screw, the woman making notes could not photograph my retina with the new machine and brought out the old machine that hums like kindness and that one took an image that made her say, "Weird," and then "No, sorry, I shouldn’t say weird," and then "You have lovely blood vessels," which is the sort of compliment you cannot put on a dating profile. I paid full price and left and stood on the pavement and breathed the air which had decided to be windless for an afternoon.

The shaved-head man found me without his chorus that week. I was carrying too many books out of habit and trying not to drop their weight which did not feel like weight but wanted to be treated as such, like a baby who has fallen asleep and must not be told it is light. He materialised near the pet shop, a trick large men perfect. "I couldn’t hit you if I wanted," he said, like a mathematician posing a problem. "It’s not religion, before you say. I’ve done religion. It’s not that. It’s like your skin has told the air something I don’t know words for." He added, in fairness to himself, "I’m not a poet. I’m just as surprised as you." I could have run and he would have let me because there was nothing to chase. Instead I said, "Why would you want to hit me?" and he laughed, a proper laugh, and then stopped laughing and put his big hands on his big thighs and leaned down to his own height. "Because you’re making my mates look like they should be better," he said. "I don’t like any man who makes me feel like the day after Christmas." Then, like a man remembering a task his mother had given him when she could still do that, he said, "You want a word? Peace isn’t when no one looks at you. Peace is when you can bump into someone and both of you know it won’t turn into your whole afternoon." He had found poetry by accident, which is the only honest way. I thanked him as if he had loaned me a spade and he nodded and said, "Don’t be a twat," which is love in a dialect.

Ellie organised a leaving-not-leaving gathering in her flat that Saturday and the house smelled of coriander and beer and paper plates that had died bravely. I went early to help and managed to lift the folding table with an appropriate grunt; sometimes the world accepts your application to be corporeal on a temporary basis. People came: the librarian who lives in the basement, two of Ellie's work friends who brought stories that began with the words "you know what it’s like," a couple from across the street who had that closeness that suggests they should not share a hobby. Rafe arrived late with mud on his knees and a new dent in his boot, apologised to Ellie with his whole face, and then saw me and made a small gesture with his hand in front of his own shoulder as if miming a touch he had decided not to attempt. We spoke about nails as if they were a topic; he told me he had discovered that things hold best when the first nail is not in the obvious place. "Everything is a cross-bracing," he said, and I thought of sentences that lean on other sentences so they do not fall. Someone put on a song from ten years ago and we all pretended we had not liked it then and liked it now. I stood by the window and a moth battered itself against the pane and found me as useful as the glass.

The bus-station board went up and the town did what towns do: they ignored it for two days and then fought about it as if it had taken the last biscuit. The first week’s numbers were disappointing and then astonishing, in that order. On Tuesday a pile of takeaway boxes was left tidily around the base and no one wanted to press a button that would look like pride; on Thursday an old woman in a fawn coat pressed the corner button seventeen times in a row because she thought the system was broken when it asked her to wait between presses. A boy took a picture of his friend pressing and another boy shouted, "Grass!" and the man from the bicycle shop came out and said, "It’s not grass if we all know, you daft sod," and the boy blushed. The chalked sum rose on Sunday like a harvest, not a total, and when the Council brought their green cupcakes a wind carried one onto the pavement icing-down and we all decided not to be superstitious about it. I stood to one side and felt like a man watching a paper boat navigate a puddle with the dignity of ships.

I did not go to Eindhoven. I wrote to the coordinator and said that my passport had been borrowed by a cat, and then wrote again and said I was sorry and told the truth: that I could not guarantee I would set the right kind of weight on a hotel bed to make it believe in me. She wrote back with generosity that made me ache; she said they had anticipated this because cameras had refused me before and would I consider speaking through a medium that did not insist on outlining me. "We will record a voice and show your pages," she said. "It will make the students imagine a better man than you are." I sent her a file of sentences and pictures of my whiteboard and a short clip of ribbons at the keep moving in a wind that had changed its mind twice in a minute. Afterwards, a student from Antwerp wrote: "Your third thing is a fourth thing to us," and I thought how beautiful it is that the same scaffolding has different floors in other languages.

Blackmere flourished under attention without softening. That was the joy of it. Scaffolding made a geometry the ruin did not resent. The teenagers no longer came to drink there as often because they had to climb ladders instead of stairs and that felt too much like effort. Couples came and took pictures, and both of them became taller in the shadow in the way people do when they put a ruin behind them to make their own faces modern. Ribbons multiplied and faded and were replaced by other fabrics with other histories in them. An old man tied a slip of striped cloth that had been a pyjama and would not say why. A girl took a pair of pink laces out of a shoe and knotted them together and hung them in such a way that you could not decide if she had done it as a joke or as a vow. The owl learned our rhythm and began to hunt at different hours and left pellets like punctuation where we would see them and be honoured. Rafe found a niche where a saucepan fit and heated water there on a camping burner and we drank tea that tasted like flint and was better for it.

On a Wednesday between wind and rain, I walked the Roman wall for the first time since that first week in which everything had started to raise its eyebrows. I kept Rafe’s father’s rhythm—old stones and new stones in a jag as if I were refusing to be in time with both—and at Vineyard Gate a man with a red scarf asked me if I knew the dates. I told him none of us knows any dates and then, because he looked like he would take that as permission to be worse, I gave him the century and he smiled and said, "Thank you. I needed to place myself," and walked on counting something with his fingers. We all count. We count steps, breaths, times forgiven, times we did not knock. The wall smelled as walls do when rain finds the old, like books that have been in suitcases.

Ellie began to pack her flat upstairs into boxes that said FRAGILE in a handwriting that did not believe it. She came down at odd hours to ask me whether she should keep the plant that had tried so hard and failed, whether she should tell her new manager about her father, whether it was cowardice to love a town and leave it. I told her yes to all of it and then no to all of it and we laughed. On the night before the van came, we sat on her floor and ate greasy food from cartons and watched a show in which people who were not us negotiated rooms with large sofas and mirrors that told them every day that they were enough. When she cried, she did it the way tidy people do: without noise, with her face in her own shoulder so no one would see the map of it later. I wanted to comfort her with a hand on a forearm, that old civilised gesture, but my hand was busy being an idea and so I told her the story of the old man and the pyjama ribbon and it worked better; she laughed and then sighed and said, "I will need a London ritual," and I wrote on the nearest box with a Sharpie: Buy a ribbon.

There is a dream you keep, and mine kept the table with the white surface that asks for stains. The chairs filled and emptied, and finally the empty chair stopped shining and simply was. When I spoke in the dream I could hear my voice as if from another room, the room where the kettle makes its private concert. I explained again, for an audience who had scars in places I could not see, that the condition under which conflict ceases without force is the presence of an alternative ritual with a better yield on belonging and less penalty for the average lie. They nodded, all of them, and one of them—his hair had softened with age in that way hair does when it forgives the skull—said, "You are late," and I wanted to ask late for what but I woke with the owl’s vowel in my mouth.

It would be untrue to say that people began to stop me in the street and declare peace. They stopped me and declared their need to be fair to their own need, which is a kind of honesty too. A man in a paint-stained hoodie told me he had used the bus-station board to count his cigarettes because his wife had threatened to leave if the number went above fifty. A girl with a hoop in her nose told me she had kissed a boy she did not like because he had done five things and she had done none and this felt like an equaliser; I told her to cure herself of that and she said, "I know," and smiled with the relief of recognising the poison while drinking it. A Council woman with a scarf like a flag said, "It’s working," and then, in the same breath, "We have decided to convene a committee," and I felt my teeth ache with the effort of not saying what I wanted to say about committees.

I sent Maria—the mother of a boy I tutor who believes numbers are for punishing mistakes—an exercise in which the numbers were animals and you had to group them by affection rather than size. She called and said, "You have made my son cry in a way I am not angry about," which I took as a letter of recommendation. The house continued to be itself and less. The fridge hummed when I insulted it aloud and remained silent when I praised it. A parcel arrived and when I opened the door the delivery driver shouted, "Hello?" past me as if I were a ghost refusing to answer. I took the box and put it on the table and it left the faintest damp ring and I found that ring beautiful in the way one finds handprints on windows beautiful when the hands are not your own.

Rafe told me his full name on a day so windy the ribbons were singing like a choir of bad sopranos. He said it into his coat collar as if it would try to escape him otherwise. "Rafe Elgar Alder," he said. "The middle name is the gift of a father who loved trains and wanted a son to be a civilisation." I said that Elgar would forgive him for being stonework and tea and he shrugged the way a man shrugs, which is to say like a man lifting an unwieldy story. He slept one night up there on a mattress that had seen better walls and came down in the morning with a new caution in his ankles and a story about the kind of dark you do not get in town. "The sort that has your name in it," he said. "You think it’s following you and then you realise you have drawn it with your own shadow, which is mortifying and a relief."

When the scaffolding reached the height of the second landing and the foreman said, "This’ll stop her for a while," the owl left a pellet on the top bar as if signing a document. Rafe held out his hand and I held out mine because that is what friends do when there should be warm congratulations and a shaking of fingers. Our hands stopped a brace-width from each other, hovered, became the diagram of a handshake, and we left them there long enough that the foreman snorted and went to shout at a man who had tied something wrong. Rafe laughed then, not at me but at the absurdity, and said, "We will find a third thing for this too," and I said, "We will become the kind of men who clap across rooms," and we did, once, like fools, just to own the joke before someone else could wound us with it.

The night the ribbon arch was torn, it did not feel like a defeat. We arrived at eight with a flask and saw the colours pulled and knotted and scorched at the ends where a lighter had convinced them to try being smoke. The boys had been there and had been bored by their own strength and then had become inventive and impatient in the same breath. I picked up a scrap of tablecloth with gravy in its history and tied it back where it would catch the east wind. Rafe said, "Of course," and set about retieing until his fingers were a language. A man walked past with a dog that looked like it had once been a cloud and said, "Morning," and kept his judgments to himself. When we left, the arch looked like a dented crown and that felt appropriate; nothing should be immaculate in a place meant for keeping.

I began to write again, not for the internet, but for the dull devotion of my own head. Pages about apologies that repair us without making us indebted to the apology, about the design of a queue that calms the neck instead of claiming it, about teaching as a lending of spine more than a lending of information. I wrote a paragraph about chairs, how we assign them status and then resent the chairs for knowing more about us than we do, and then went and sat in the worst chair in the house to punish myself for the sentence. At three in the morning, the house sounded like the sea does when you are too far inland for there to be a sea. I stood in the hall so I would not wake myself with my own turning and held a page against my chest and felt nothing through the paper and then everything, a delayed echo of body; if you have ever hugged someone who was crying and only realised thirty seconds later that you were crying too, you will know the feeling.

On a Sunday we held a small event at Blackmere which we refused to call an event. Rafe made sandwiches that had the confidence to be old-fashioned, and I brought a thermos and a bundle of spare ribbons, and three women from the dry-cleaner brought a table with lace that had the weight of iron. People came up the path because the path had decided to exist for them. A child tied a ribbon around his own wrist instead of the arch and declared himself kept. A man who sang in the choir at St James’s stood with his mouth closed and looked as if he were warming up. A teenager stood in the doorway and pretended to look at his phone while looking at us and then asked, without meeting my gaze, "If I pick up five bottles, does that count for someone else?" and I said, "Yes," and he said, "Good," and did it. We did not clap. We nodded, because nodding is the village version of applause. Late in the afternoon, as the light fell with the gusto of late winter and the tea went metallic in its cooling, I told the small circle that had coalesced the thing about mutual audit and humiliation, and the choir man put his hands in his coat and told me he had once stolen a tin of peaches and that the woman at the till had watched him and said nothing and that he had never stolen again and had given twenty peaches away that year as if he owed someone something that could not be named. "If you make me a board that says peaches, I’ll press it," he said, and there we were: ridiculous and real.

That evening the street outside my window reflected a sky that had missed a cue and stayed an hour too long. I pressed my hand to the glass and felt my own pulse through my wrist but not through the pane, which ought to be true anyway and now felt like a statement. Someone had scrawled a new message on the wall opposite over the correct paint and it was not about me; it was about football, and I wanted to hug men I had never met. The gull returned to the pole and looked older, if that is possible with a beak and an expression you know only because you have anthropomorphised it to keep yourself company. He regarded me with his efficient eye and then looked away, as if granting me the same mercy. I went to bed and dreamed I was a ribbon, which is as embarrassing as it sounds, and woke up laughing at myself, which helped.

In the days that followed, the Council’s board broke because children discovered that buttons want to be pressed in rhythms, and the council replaced it with a lever and people adapted, and I smiled because we are cleverer in groups than we are one at a time. The shaved-head man waved to me outside the siege house and did not cross the road, which felt like a treaty. Ellie sent me a picture of a London street that had tried too hard to be a village and said, "They’ve tied ribbons here," and I messaged back a picture of our arch with the wind combing it to within an inch of its dignity. Rafe called me from the top of the scaffold and described to me the colour of the neighbouring field as if he were the painter and could not get the green right without my approval. The owl, at dusk, flew low and slow along the inner wall and turned its head to the rib of the arch and for a second I thought it would touch the fabric with its wing. It did not. It carried on, as if not touching were its own ritual. I stood very still and pretended that stillness was a thing I had chosen rather than inherited.I began to test the world the way a child tests the edge of a pool before committing to the cold. Salt on the back of my hand remained a line rather than a flavour; heat from the hob stayed in the realm of sight until I held a metal spoon above it for a while and let the spoon carry the message to me like a postman who preferred not to knock. I found that pressure kept its contract if it had been negotiated in advance; a book placed in my bag would weigh me honestly all day, whereas a book lifted quickly off a table was a promise made with fingers crossed. In the mirror I practised expressions that would reassure tired people and decided that the best I could do was to look as if I had slept near someone who trusted me. When I wrote the date on the board that Monday the numbers looked competent, which is all you want from a date; the pen squeaked and I heard the squeak in the way you hear an old story told to someone else on a bus and pretend not to listen while arranging yourself to catch every third word.

Ellie phoned to ask if I would come to the station and stand in the unimportant part of her leaving, which is to say the part where you pretend you have enough hands for bag, wallet, ticket, coat, and goodbye. We stood by the vending machine that has always carried one row of things no one has bought since 2003 and she issued instructions to me as if I were the train: call my mother once a week and lie to her about the quality of London air, check that the plant upstairs goes to a better home than the bin, keep hearing the cello through the ceiling even when there is no ceiling. The barrier swallowed her ticket and then questioned her and we laughed because it was the only honest reaction to a machine that wants an explanation. She reached to hug me and remembered halfway and turned the embrace into a small theatre of arms in which both of us participated. We invented a ritual instead: three taps of the knuckles on the metal of the barrier and then one breath together counted aloud to five, because counting aloud makes a moment communal. She untied the ribbon from her wrist—the one she had mock-practised drawing cats with—and tied it around my watch with a knot I would not be able to undo without admitting I had tried. When the train came, it came with the urgency of excuses, and she went through the door and sat by the window and put her hand up as people do when they are saying I can go now, I can go now, I have gone, thank you for making it a ceremony. After the carriage slid from the platform I stayed to watch the departures board change its verbs and thought, not without malice toward myself, that I have always liked trains best when they are leaving me behind.

The bus-station lever gathered a life as a stray gathers names. Children invented a sequence that made the light flicker in a way the Council had not anticipated; pensioners adopted the thing as a companionable affront to gravity and twitched it on their way past as if the street itself were a stubborn window. The shaved-head man found me there one afternoon with his hands empty and his jaw unclenched and stood with his back to the wall as if entrances made him nervous. "I’m Lee," he said, as if the name had been a fine he had decided to pay. "You said something about a bag in a cellar once." He meant the West Ham nights that end with glass and fidelity on the floor. I told him the bag was a start and the ritual was the better part; you want a rope to hit and a bell to ring so the room knows what to praise. "We put a nail in the beam," he said, testing me, and I told him to put two, diagonally, so the bag’s weight would insist on staying, and he nodded with the satisfaction of a man who has been given permission to do a thing properly. At the Siege House later that week, a low sinuous thumping came from below during the second half and when West Ham lost by the exact number of points that ruin your appetite, no glass broke and a cheer rose that had nothing to do with football; rituals leak from basements if you do them long enough.

Blackmere learned our names the way a teacher learns a class: in the order of trouble. The scaffolders swore in a dialect that put the vowels in the places a church would have wanted them, and built a temporary geometry that made the ruin look like a thought being taken seriously. On the second day of planks a board flexed under Rafe with a private argument about leverage and he flung his weight the correct way without thinking, which is a trick the body learns somewhere around thirty and must be thanked for. I saw his face make the calculation and my whole chest wrote him a letter in a language I did not know I had, and afterwards he laughed and called me a grandmother and then did not laugh and leaned against the crenellation that had not existed for two hundred years and breathed as if he had been given a permission slip to carry on. We tried an experiment that was as foolish as it was necessary. He fetched a dishcloth from the bucket and we folded it twice and each took one end and shook like men sealing a ridiculous compact in a long novel. The cloth accepted us both without protest. His palm warmed my fingers through the weave and my fingers made a temperature statement in return, and there we were: a handshake with a hinge. "Third thing," Rafe said, eyes alight in the way that makes a man look younger without any treachery. "We will always carry a cloth." I told him that if anyone asked we were forming a cult and the entry requirement was an understanding of laundry.

The Council tried to annex the ribbons with a campaign they called Hands Across the Borough, which sounded like an attempt to tie people up with their own enthusiasm. Their graphic had seven hands in seven colours and the same number of unconvincing smiles. A woman called me and proposed a calendar of ribbon-days, a sponsorship opportunity, a QR code that would place your generosity in a spreadsheet shaped like applause. I wrote back to say that humiliation begins at the point where the cloth wants for a name; that a ribbon is a record, not a certificate; that you do not need a mayor to open a habit. To their credit, they listened with the air of people who had once been taught to pass exams and wanted now to pass themselves. They adjusted the plan until it was not a plan at all, only a suggestion folded under a stone on a wall: if you tie, tie quietly; if you photograph, show the sky more than the hand. The first week the ladies from the dry-cleaner tied strips cut from uncollected suits that would never be claimed, and the wind turned failed interviews into a chorus. I liked the way failure can become decoration if you cut it thin.

Nadia wrote again with a letter that had lost all its embarrassment and kept all its courage. Her father had drunk on Tuesday and called her on Wednesday to apologise the way a man apologises to his own mother; she had forgiven him in a way that kept her spine; they had eaten their Friday chicken standing up because sitting had felt like a concession to sadness. "What is the ritual when it fails?" she asked in a last paragraph that deserved prayers if I had believed in them. I told her about scaffolding, about cross-bracing, about how Rafe says you do not put the first nail in the obvious place; then I told her about chalk on a kitchen calendar for days he arrived and left with the same weight, and about the rule that Fridays were for boring TV and tidy plates and an agreed nap. "If you miss one, you add another," I wrote. "Not to punish; to give yourself a row to hoe that does not depend on anyone else being excellent." A month later she sent a picture of a calendar with fifteen rectangles coloured in with pencil in the same shade of blue as the sky on a good morning for walking; she wrote, "We are cheating in our favour," which is how a civilisation begins.

Teaching turned to the left and found a better-looking street. Marian brought Caesar to me with a line she could not get across without treading water, and in the blank she said, "He read it. He didn’t understand, but he told me he would read it when he wasn’t that man. He doesn’t know how to be not-that-man yet." She had tied a thread to a word and was dragging her father across a sentence one night at a time. Elliot appeared with just enough pride to be angry at himself about it and announced that he had told his mother about a thing he had broken in June and that she had merely put a bowl in front of him and made him identify every sound the world has when it is angry and not directed at you. He said, with theatrical misery, that he had missed ten minutes of a game to do this and that the bowl had contained peas and he could now tell the difference between anger at a pan and anger at a man. I introduced apology tokens into the room—scraps of paper with words like mended, told, returned—and made them place the token on the word on the board that best fit their day. It was foolish and they knew it, and they did it with the seriousness of fools who understand better games when they see them. At the end of the week I wrote my own token and did not say to whom it belonged.

Lee decided to know me in daylight. He arrived at Blackmere while we were arguing the angle at which the first of the replaced stones should meet its neighbour and stood with the posture of a man who had once done time and had learned to make his body smaller than its shadow. Without saying hello he unwound a strip from a work shirt that had once been hi-vis and had been washed so much the colour had retreated to the thread, and tied it at knee height where only children and dogs would see it. "This place made my mate call me at three and tell me he’d had enough of the pub," he admitted after three minutes of weather. "I came up to make sure it wasn’t a trick. I suppose I’ll have to come again if it is." He told us he had a son he was better at loving on even-numbered days and that he had told the boy he would bring him to see an owl that makes men speak in paragraphs. Rafe said the owl had standards and Lee snorted and sat on the lower stone and told us his mother had once hidden a gold coin in his sock drawer to make him feel like the house had chosen him. Before he left he looked at my shoulder and said, "I still don’t understand you. But I reckon if we had a row you’d make it to the end of the sentence," which is friendship in a dialect too.

Nights, when the town rehearsed its own sleep with the sincerity of dress rehearsals, I took myself to the wall and walked its line with Rafe’s father’s rhythm. There is a corner where the air holds the shape of an apple for reasons I cannot explain, and there, one night, the old man in the red jumper sat and patted the space beside him in a manner that refuses to be what it is, which is kind. We spoke about dates without naming any, which is a trick people over a certain age teach themselves out of either modesty or strategy. He told me he had once run a model railway that would have impressed the god of small things and that he had stopped when the trains began to arrive before he had laid the track. "It was cheating," he said. "It was a gift. I didn’t want it." I told him that if a door opens for you unasked you should at least peer round it, and he grimaced at the sentiment and then nodded because the night was doing its work on us both. When he stood he put his hand out and I did not take it and he put it back without being offended, and that is how I knew he had known soldiers.

A storm came with the drama of a man arriving late and noisy to a party he had not been invited to. The first gust took the cheap things, as storms do, and flung them into corners where everything down there becomes a museum of other days. The second gust put its shoulder politely to the scaffolding and asked it to reconsider. Ribbons took their cue and made music in the only choir that does not need tone. We had tied the arch too well for the vandalism of wind to do what boredom could not; the cloths writhed and sang and then found their new angles and held there like opinions that had been argued for once and did not need to be argued again. The owl rode a line of air up the inner shaft like a prayer mat on a good day and came out into sky with its head round the wrong way and corrected itself without fuss. In the morning someone with their own idea of ownership had painted KEEP along the base stone of the south face in thick white that made the ruin look as if it had been labelled by an earnest child. Rafe hated it on sight and loved it by noon. "Castle is for tourists; keep is the thing you do," he said, reminding himself out loud, and left the word there as if a sign were a rosary you can hold when you cannot do the thing itself.

A small television man with a ravenous camera tried to get the story, and failed because men who keep ruin rarely feed the hunger of lenses. He wanted terms like community hub and heritage activation and I wanted to say that the best thing you can do with a broken wall is to show up with a cloth and tell it what you’ve been doing with your days. He filmed anyway; the film came out with the tone of a charity advert that had forgotten what charity looks like in a town that has decided to keep itself. Online, some people called us smug and some called us saints and some called us both at once, which is more accurate than you would think. A boy sent me a clip of himself tying a ribbon somewhere that was not Blackmere at all—a car park underpass with the acoustics of a church that had been turned into a place for shouting—and wrote: "Your castle is under the A12 now." It felt like being paid in currency I could never spend.

On the day after Ellie’s text about London ribbons, I found a parcel on my mat tied with string that had done other duties in its life. Inside was a cloth the colour of patience. It was not new. It had been a tablecloth, perhaps, or a curtain that had been cut to save its best part.
