The note with it said, in her handwriting that has always looked like it is rooted in a sensibler country than the one the rest of us buckle: "For handshakes. For doors that don’t know how to be doors. For when you need to pretend to be a better object." I took it to the keep and Rafe and I tried it by the light of a morning that had forgiven the storm. The cloth took the warmth from us and returned it and I felt the world reconsider me, not as a body in a room but as a noun doing its duty. Later that day, a girl with a nose-ring asked if she could borrow it for a moment; she wrapped it around her boyfriend’s wrist like a plural and kissed him through it with a seriousness that resembled prayer. I left them to their own doctrine.

The bus-station lever broke after a fortnight because everything honest breaks in a fortnight. Children had discovered that you could play a tune on it; men in their fifties had discovered that if you press something enough times it becomes an answer to the day. The Council replaced it with a handle you had to pull and the world accepted the change with a magnanimity that should have cost more. Someone wrote on the pavement below in chalk, not a slogan but an instruction: "If you pull, notice." The letters smudged in the rain and came back the next day in a different hand and that was better; a ritual that survives translation is worth keeping.

A boy in my Thursday class arrived with a bandage across his knuckles and a story he did not want to tell about a door and a perceived slight and the way testosterone wears a coat with too many pockets. I made him write an apology that did not use the words I’m sorry and he glared at me until the glare became concentration. The apology he wrote filled half a page and included the phrase "I failed at the waiting part," which made me forgive him in a way that did not make him indebted to me. I gave him a token that said waited and he took it the way soldiers take water. Marian, who had begun to bring a ribbon with her in the pocket of her coat as if it were a talisman or a threat, made a habit of knotting it around the strap of her bag and untying it again when she left; she told me she did not want to be the sort of woman who keeps symbols hostage and then immediately laughed at herself, which is the closest most of us get to holiness.

Rafe spoke, on the second Tuesday after the storm, about fear with an ease that was not ease at all. We were on the north side where the crack had begun to look like a man mending his trousers alone by a lamp, and we had the cloth between us because it had become a joke, which is to say a defence. "I am afraid of the day I put steel in here and the wall forgives me too quickly," he admitted, rolling a screw across his palm with the deliberation of prayer beads. "I don’t trust anything that does not ask me to come back twice." I told him I was afraid of the conditions under which a man might be dead without noticing and he nodded as if I had said something about the weather and then did not nod because the weather had decided to be personal. We tied a black ribbon low on the arch for every fear we named, not as tally but as company. By the time the foreman came to tell us he had found a better angle for the braces, there were seven and the wind had taught them to speak to each other without lying.

Lee turned up with his son on a morning when the town had the good manners to be undecided between rain and sunlight. The boy had a face like a new pound coin and a voice that tried on laughter and kept it. He stood in the doorway and refused to move and then moved all at once, which is what boys do before they decide which men they will have to forgive. He pressed the back of his hand against the stone and declared it honest and his father asked him how he knew and he said, with the confidence of fifteen, "Because it doesn’t want anything from me," and Rafe, who has never wanted anything from a person he could not obligingly get for himself, looked away in case anyone noticed that the sentence had landed. The boy tied the laces from his shoes to the lowest bar of the scaffold and hopped back to town, favouring the right foot, laughing at his own impertinence. Later, at the bus-station lever, I watched the same boy steady an old woman by the elbow with the air of a man who has finally discovered the point of his hands.

That night I lay in bed and counted not sheep but frets: the spaces where a finger falls to make a note be itself. The house made the sea again for me and I thought of all the rooms in which people were naming their fears to the air in case someone else took them before the air could decide what to do. Peace, I decided, is not a room you can always get back to. It is a route with more than one landmark. If the kettle fails you, there is the lever by the bus station; if the lever breaks, there is the ribbon on the arch; if the ribbon is torn, there is the cloth in your pocket; if the cloth frays, there is the old wall at night and the man who will sit with you and not take your hand. I slept then, without asking permission, and woke to the sound of a bird making an argument for morning with both insistence and reason, which is all any of us can hope for in our better speeches.

The next day a letter arrived from the university in Glasgow, the kind headmaster’s city, inviting me to a smaller room than Eindhoven had proposed. They wanted me to come and talk to twenty people who had designed parks that children ignored and ask them if the swings might swing for acts other than joy. I put the letter under the clock and the clock, as ever, gave it neither blessing nor doom. I thought of trains and barriers that swallow tickets and rituals that know when to break and when to bend. I wrote to say I would come if they would permit me a cloth on the lectern and an agreement that no one would try to make a handshake of me. They wrote back with good humour to say that Scotland was full of cloth and that the lectern had seen worse.

By the week’s end the arch at Blackmere wore more colour than a small nation and the scaffold had become the kind of geometry men call handsome because it works. The owl took a small rabbit with the casual cruelty of necessity and we all looked away as if politeness were a mercy we had invented recently. On the town wall, a boy practised parkour, which is the ancient art of refusing to accept the obvious route, and cleared the gap by the King’s Head with a shout that made three old ladies smile in terror. At the Siege House, Carl hit the bag in the cellar and laughed at himself afterwards the way a man laughs when he has given the day less work to do. Ellie sent me a picture of her desk in London that had been cleaned by someone else and wrote, "They have a rule about mugs that will kill me," and I sent her a picture of our cloth-joined hands held an inch apart with the keep behind like a joke only we could tell. Somewhere in all this, the town decided to test my agreement in small ways I cannot list. A door that had been hard to open opened. A man who had always been late arrived on time and said nothing. A girl pressed the bus-station handle with her elbow because her hands were busy with flowers, and the numbers rose as if numbers could be kind.Chapter 6 begins with a ticket that does not mind being held by a man who is half-in and a cloth folded twice over my palm so a conductor will not have to perform the etiquette of touching the invisible. I said yes to Glasgow because saying no had begun to sound like another version of hiding, and because trains are long pieces of ritual laid across a country with the hope that we will behave better in carriages than we do in kitchens. The morning I left, the gull watched me go with the managerial disinterest of a creature who has seen enough departures to know which ones matter, and the bus to the station hissed like a boiling pan and forgave me for not feeling its floor. At the barrier I tapped the metal with my knuckles three times as Ellie and I had agreed in our invented liturgy and breathed to five with a woman whose lipstick was the shade of cherries you pick too early, and the machine decided I was a person and let me through.

On the train, men made calls to their own lives with the privacy of priests and a boy ate crisps as if trying to prove salt was still legal. I chose a seat by the window because nothing asks less of you than a view that does not need your approval, and the carriage did that thing carriages do where two strangers rehearse being neighbours without ever speaking: sharing armrests like disputed borders, choosing to look out rather than in, letting the air be a third party that holds the silence up at the corners so it does not sag. The trolley woman asked me if I wanted tea and I said yes, foolishly, because I like to test the world at its edges, and when the cup passed from her hand to mine through the cloth it felt like having your name said correctly by a kind stranger. The tea itself tasted like the idea of tea written on a blackboard in too much chalk, which is to say the caffeine did its duty and the flavour sent me home to the kettle that knows its role.

Somewhere past Peterborough the sky remembered Scotland and began to practise. The light shifted from the Essex insistence that everything belongs to somebody to a northern confidence that nothing belongs to anyone for long, and the fields arranged themselves like arguments that had been settled by stone walls. A child in the aisle was taught by his mother how to match the rhythm of the train with the rhythm of his steps, and when he succeeded he applauded himself without shame and we all benefited a little from the honesty. I wrote on the back of the Glasgow invitation with a pen that had forgiven me its caps, a list of things swings can count that are not only joy: stitches between fights; minutes you wait for someone without resenting them; the number of times a boy drops his shoulders before choosing not to throw the first punch. Across from me a woman plaited her hair with the concentration of a surgeon and every time she tugged the end she checked her reflection in the window where the opposite seats lived like flickering ghosts of other journeys.

The city greeted me as a place that has made peace with rain in all its dialects and has decided not to talk about it any more than necessary. I stayed in a room whose bed was the sort that makes a promise it does not intend to keep and whose curtains had learned to be heavy without being dark, and I placed the cloth on the chair like an animal that needs to be told it is safe. On the walk to the university I crossed a street that did not notice me and had my first full measure of vertigo: not the drop but the absence of it, a sense that the tarmac was a photograph held at a distance. A woman with a bag that said fresh rolls in a font that would have made a graphic designer roll their eyes put her hand to my sleeve through the cloth and tugged with a briskness that brooked no argument, and I stumbled into solidity the way you stumble into a joke you did not realise was yours to tell. She did not look at me after; she executed an act of neighbourliness and kept a Glasgow pace, which is to say she gave me the dignity of being a man who knows where he is going even when he does not.

The room for the talk had the air of having been built for better arguments than the ones it hosts, as many academic rooms do. There were twenty people, as promised, and two windows that watched us with the patience of old dogs, and a lectern that had seen hands thump and hands flutter and hands fold like paper birds. I placed the cloth on the wood as if laying out bread and asked, as my price for talking, that anyone who wanted to ask a question put a square of paper down on the cloth first with a word on it, so we would know which register we were speaking in: fear, habit, audit, shame, belonging, boredom, sport. The first word was boredom, which comforted me more than I can say; utopias die of boredom and so, sometimes, do dictatorships. I spoke about swings and handrails and the moral architecture of playgrounds, about the way a sandbox can keep the peace if you agree together that the sand wants to be returned to itself at the end of the day, about counting not as surveillance but as courtesy. I said that a promise you can see is kinder than a promise you can only suspect, that you can nudge a street to keep itself if you give it a point to move around and a weatherproof pen.

Afterwards a man whose shoes were very clean introduced himself as the headmaster from the letter and told me, with a gentleness men reserve for each other when they know the other has been trying, that I was late and that he was glad. He took me to a playground in the shadow of a tower that had been designed when men thought height alone would solve loneliness, and the swings there squeaked at the edges where chains suspect their own mortality. The designer, a woman whose hair had the pragmatism of a builder’s pencil, had built a wall you could write on with chalk that was stored in a rainproof box and a hinged board where children could slide a marker from need to done with the force of three fingers. There were small hooks for ribbons that had been used exactly once and kept for years and the hooks had become the ritual more than the fabric had, the reminder that one day someone would tie something again. The headmaster told me the children had invented a game where you could only have a turn on the highest swing if you made a younger child laugh first, and I thought it was the best governance I had heard all week.

I confess I expected Glasgow to treat the cloth like an eccentricity and was humbled to have three separate people bring me their own fabric to be blessed by use. A woman called Morag with a scar she did not pretend to hide told me she ties a strip of her mother’s apron to the dog’s lead when she takes him out on nights she is afraid she will choose the river over the bridge, and she asked me if she could lay it on the cloth while I spoke about apology tokens. A man called Tariq who runs a youth club where the football and the poetry have learned not to flinch at each other’s names carried a tea towel embroidered with the year of his wedding and said he uses it when he is too angry to say grace and it says grace for him by inhabiting the table. They did not need me, is what I realised. They had built the apparatus already and were only indulging me by letting me name it as if naming were the same as keeping.

I walked back to my room in a rain that had the decency to be honest about its intentions, and on the way a bus refused to see me in the old style and a boy with headphones the size of emergency landings put an arm out like a barrier and swore without hatred. There was a doorway with a sign offering cheap haircuts that looked like a door I had walked through once in another life, and I stood in its shelter and watched a man wipe his glasses with a scarf that had lived more years in Glasgow than I had in Colchester. In the room, the television showed men in suits talking about the price of bread as if bread were a luxury and two women in a white kitchen promised me they could make my surfaces forget their past. I wrote to Ellie, a real letter because London has a way of making the digital feel like confetti, and told her about the woman with the apron and the hooks in the playground and the way the city holds its own as if strength were friendly rather than competitive. She replied with a photograph of a meeting room with a wall of glass that looked onto another wall of glass and wrote, "They have a ritual about coffee mugs here; the punishment is humour," and I understood.

Rafe sent me three pictures in quick succession as if he did not trust himself to write sentences for fear he would grow sentimental and have to forgive himself. The first showed the steel lying like careful bones against the grass. The second showed the foreman leaning against the north wall with his thumb at a new angle like a unit of pride he could loan out. The third showed the owl perched on the highest crossbar with the expression of a magistrate hearing a case about a crime it does not consider criminal. He appended, because he is not a man to leave a joke unclasped, "The owl approves the bracing," and a small drawing of a feather and a nail, which is as much as Rafe will allow himself of tenderness with men.

On the second day they took me to a housing estate where someone clever had painted a wall with the outline of a larder and invited residents to hang a paper with either give or need written at the top, and the miracle was not that people gave tins of tomatoes and bags of rice but that the space between those two words began to fill with messages like walk with me on Tuesday at six or I can sit with your baby for an hour if you bring me a picture of your mother. A community worker with a voice that turned sarcasm into mercy told me their biggest problem had been men who wanted to convert every kindness into numbers and win, and that the trick had been to build a habit of untallying: a weekly ritual of going to the board and wiping off the totals with a single sleeve, as if it were the end of a game we were glad to have played but more glad to have finished. I wrote that down so hard I nearly broke the pen. If my agreement has an appendix, it is this: there must be ceremonies of forgetting or else the numbers will bleed us of our gentleness.

On my last evening I ate soup in a place that understood the hierarchy of heat and salt, and a man at the bar told me, unasked, about the way his brother had built a railway in the attic and kept it private so it would not have to perform. He said his brother died and he had gone up there and found the trains would only run if you whistled the first bar of a tune their father had loved, and I thought of clocks that will not tick unless they are watched and of doors that turn into walls when you have said your name too loudly on the threshold. Glasgow makes old stories walk slower so we can catch them. I slept in a bed that believed me and woke to a rain that made friends with the light and the train took me south with the politeness of an apology that has learned not to over-explain.

Back in Colchester the station had arranged itself into the shape of my life as if it had been practising while I was gone. The barrier took my ticket with the air of a man not angry any more but not ready to be fond, and in the taxi rank a driver explained to me without preamble that politics had become a pub argument conducted in bearpit accents and that he longed for a bureaucracy he could mutter about without fearing for his neighbours. On Queen Street the lever had sprouted a laminated note in a teacher’s handwriting asking people to pull properly, which is to say not at speed, and someone had written underneath in pen, "Define properly," and the council had added a sticker that said, "With care," and I wanted to choke on my own joy. On the wall opposite my house the paint was still good and the gull lifted his beak and put it down again in a way that implied toleration rather than welcome.

The keep had become a geometry so handsome it flirted. The steel sat bright against the old stone like a young idea in an elderly brain and I could see, as soon as I stepped into the field and the nettles made their proper case against my shins, that the north crack had settled into a truce. The ribbons survived the storm like sailors with stories, frayed and proud and replaced in places with new fabric that did not yet know wind. Rafe met me at the entry with the grin he saves for good news that has not asked to be applauded and said, "I put the first brace in at the angle you told me not to and it worked," which is how he apologises. We shook the cloth between us and it felt for a moment like we had invented together a piece of physics the world had been using without thanking us.

The notice came a week later and it was a piece of paper with language that had learned to be sorrowful without being sad. The estate had found a clause in a clause that made a briefcase lick its lips and a crest had decided to reassert itself. A planning notice stood at the lane like a man with a clipboard and said in careful ink that a question had been asked about the future of our ruin and that we were entitled, as members of the public in good standing, to reply. Rafe held the paper the way you hold a verdict you do not recognise and then put it on the mantelpiece where the clock misbehaves, and we stood and watched it not tick and decided that whatever a clause says a ribbon can answer. I wrote to the headmaster and he wrote back the next day with links to men who had fought clauses with jam roly-poly and jam roly-poly had won. The foreman said, "Lawyers are just scaffolders with better shoes," and I felt my shoulders forgive him for the simile.

We built a ritual that was not a protest because protests are good at making a noise and bad at making a habit. We called it listening because the leaflet wanted us to say objection and we were tired of being opposites all day. Over a weekend we sat under the arch in shifts with a thermos that had not known rest for twenty-four hours, and anyone could come and tell the wall what it had done for them and anyone could tie something that had failed them to the rope and leave it to learn a better use. A man brought a shoe that had walked him to a divorce court and a woman brought a tie from a job she had been sacked from because she had not smiled enough and a child brought a homework sheet that had been marked wrong for being too right and they tied them all in a cluster like a small, defiant museum of personal defeats. Lee came and stood on the outer step and said nothing and then said, "My boy thinks this place is the sound a kettle makes before it boils," and I thought I would forgive him anything for giving me that. We wrote all these things not in a ledger because ledgers make good men bad, but on a sheet of paper we burned in the brazier near dusk each day, the smoke going into the sky with whatever smoke takes and then forgets, which is its great kindness.

In the middle of it a woman with a voice like a radio presenter and a face like a girl who never trusted a camera arrived with a cameraman and wanted to ask questions in a way that made the answers feel like napkins at a picnic. Rafe is braver than I am in the soft ways and went to meet her and spoke about keeping without calling the place a castle and about steel being a kind of love when it is used to hold rather than to fence, and in the middle of a sentence he tripped on a stone he should not have tripped on and fell in stages, which was worse. There is a choreography men perform in the second after their own ankle betrays them where pride tries to negotiate with pain and loses. We had the cloth in our stupid pocket, and I had it out before either of us thought, and the piece of fabric made a hinge between his palm and mine and a lever under his elbow and we got him up without giving the cameraman the victory of a hand that met skin. Rafe swore in a language that made the owl look away out of decorum and we laughed because crying is hard work and we had jobs with ribbon.

The planning notice had a date on it that acted like a countdown in a film, only no one wanted to run or kiss anyone at noon. The Council, who had learned something in their year of handles and chalk, asked if they could hold the conversation by the arch rather than in a room that eats listening, and for once they did not invite a panel. We sat on stone and a woman with a scarf like a map of the A-roads said the clause was old and no one knew why it had crept out of its drawer now, and a man with hands he would never retire asked if the word derelict still had a legal meaning if the place was now full of cups of tea and thermoses and ribbon. I said we could call it kept and he said he liked the sound of that in the minutes, and the woman with the scarf smiled as if allowing the town to reclassify itself was a perk of her job she had waited a year to use. A boy with a hoodie that had learned to be a flag for a different country shouted from the path that it was a castle whatever anyone said, and there was a cheer because sometimes being technically wrong is the only honest position you can hold with a mouth that is still learning.

Ellie, from London, sent me voice notes in which the city sounded like it was trying to finish an argument long after the other party had gone home to sleep. She told me about a woman who had introduced a ritual at her office where, at five, anyone who wanted to say "I am done being useful" could place their mug upside down as a declaration of completion, and about how three men tried to make a joke of it and were corrected by a receptionist who had learned to do kindness as mischief. She asked if she could come down for the listening and I said yes and then added that she did not have to, which is our version of consent; the next morning she sent a picture of her train ticket, the bargain kind that makes you dare the railways to be good.

On the third afternoon of listening a wind arrived that had opinions and voiced them with confidence. The ribbons learnt to remonstrate and the arch bent its noise back at them until the air between stone and fabric felt like a conversation after a long day: testy, fond, not to be recorded. A man in a suit that really belonged to a different man asked me whether the Quiet Agreement would scale to a city and I told him it should not be allowed to; that nothing good remains good if it has to fill more than a square mile because economies of scale begin to count the wrong thing as cost. He looked disappointed and relieved, which is how you know a manager has understood you. The owl took a mouse in front of a toddler who clapped at the efficiency and his mother made a face at me as if I had scheduled it, which is a compliment in the language of mothers.

The night before the date on the planning notice, Lee found me at the Siege House with a pint he did not drink and a jaw that was not trying to win any prizes. He told me the bag had saved a glass again and that his boy had asked if the downstairs was a gym or a church and he had told him church because you only go to gyms to become someone else and you go to church to remember your own name, and then he looked at my shoulder with the caution of a man who knows what he cannot hit and said, "If we lose, we still keep it," which was either wisdom or my own nonsense returning to me improved. We went together to the keep at the hour when the town has brushed its teeth and Rafe sat on a crate with his ankle in a bandage he had decided meant he was now a veteran and we drank tea that tasted like a day you do not regret. We tied three black ribbons low and did not name their fears; there is dignity in refusing to list.

The morning of the decision the field filled up the way fields do when bureaucracy meets ritual and both wear their best jumper. The Council woman with her map-scarf had brought a notebook that had never been written on and which therefore meant something to her, and the man from the estate had the politeness of a person who has never had to worry about public opinion and was unsure how to respect it without becoming ridiculous. We sat; we listened; the old man in the red jumper came and did not sit, which is how you know he was worried; a child tied the same ribbon three times because the knot felt like arithmetic. When the woman with the scarf read the words we wanted read, the words that said the clause had forgiven us for doing something useful and that the keep was to be kept in the name of anyone who wanted to keep it, there was not a cheer because cheers are for teams and there was no opposing side any more. We did what villages do when a thing has gone right after having looked briefly like it would go wrong: we exhaled and arranged to bring cake without permission.

I walked the wall that evening with Rafe’s father’s rhythm and discovered that my feet had an opinion again about wood and stone and the crack between them. The town made that sound it makes when a storm is deciding whether to announce itself and a boy practised falling safely from a low height for the pleasure of the scrape, and I thought how often we do that with our hearts. On the way home I stopped at the bus-station handle and pressed it like a man acknowledging something he had not built, and behind me a woman said, "Define properly," not as a challenge but as a suggestion and the man with her said, "With care," and the world, for the space it takes a handle to rise and fall, seemed to make sense.

I am not cured. I still hold the cloth when I have to greet what other people take for granted. But something about the steel in the north wall and the way the ribbon arch looked after a storm and the handling of a clause that could have been sharper than it chose to be began to rebuild the bridge between my foot and the floor. I practised being an object with the humility of a chair, I practised walking like a man whose weight agreed with him, I practised, which is the only statistic that matters in this. At night, the dream with the white table gave me back a twelfth chair, but this time it was not empty; it contained a coat laid across it like a promise someone intends to keep tomorrow, and that felt like a concession I did not know I needed.

Ellie came down for the weekend and smelt like a city that has decided to pretend it is not one for two days. We went to the keep and she did what she always does, which is to make the tea without needing instruction and to tell the owl she admired its haircut and to roll her eyes at men who have learned to make meaning from steel as if this were a new invention. She tied a ribbon the colour of the Underground line that had adopted her and stood back and made her thinking-teeth click and said, "You are going to be the kind of old man who lectures children about handrails," and I said, "If I am lucky," and we both meant it. Rafe liked her immediately, because she teased him on the second sentence and asked him whether he had always wanted to be a caretaker and he said, "I thought I wanted to be a failure that looked like romance; this is better," and if I have ever loved him more I do not remember when.

We walked back along the river as if it had been put there to listen, which perhaps it had. Ellie talked about an office ritual she had smuggled in under the skirts of company culture: a third Wednesday practice where everyone wrote down one thing they had done that never ended up on a performance review and put it in a bowl and read someone else’s aloud over biscuits that had learned to be humble. She said the boss tried to monetise it and was gently told to leave the biscuits alone, and I cheered for the receptionist I had never met. At the bridge near the Hythe we stopped and I put my hand to the rail and felt the cold with the honesty of metal and thought how much of peace is simply being given a chance to become bored by what once frightened you.

I tell myself, as I put chairs back where they belong and tolerate the fridge’s theatre and write exercises for Elliot that turn subjunctives into muscle memory, that keeping is not a decision you make once. It is boring on purpose and dramatic by accident. It is letting a ribbon be an answer when a clause asks a question. It is offering a cloth when the ritual of skin fails you without pretending that the cloth is a miracle. It is, above all, the willingness to make a small ceremony of the day and then to forget it so you can do it again without the numbers getting their teeth into it. The wall still waits for me at night with its old rhythm and the owl still holds its court on the second landing, and when the gull looks at me from the pole in the morning, he does it with the expression of a bird who has understood that a man might be many things at once and that the important thing is the hand on the rail when you cross the bridge.Chapter 8

Heat arrived the way an uninvited cousin arrives: loudly, with arms out, full of stories you are not ready to hear. Colchester does not trust heat. The Roman wall sulked under it and the pavements turned the colour of arguments. Bins developed a personality you would not befriend. The gull on the pole opened his beak and panted like a dog, which startled me into laughter in spite of everything. Children learned to walk in the shade of their parents’ words and dogs learned the geometry of water bowls placed outside cafés trying to look like southern European cities. Inside, the fridge’s hum sounded like a threat and the whiteboard marker inked as if reluctant to leave home.

Exams came with sweaters tied round waists, with deodorant theatrically over-applied, with the old promises: breakfast, a pen that will not betray you, a bottle of water with the label peeled off until the word spring looks like a confession. I wrote dates on the board, imperial and BBC, and felt the familiar ache of wanting to sit these tests for them and the equal urgency of knowing I could not. Marian arrived with her hair tied back in a revision knot and the look of someone who had spent three nights with Caesar as an unhelpful boyfriend. We did clauses until the room felt like a courtroom. At the end she put her head down on the table and asked, into the wood, without lifting her face, whether peace meant forgiving herself for wanting to win without working. I told her no, that peace meant designing the room so the work made more sense than the winning, and she lifted her head and made the clicking noise with her teeth that belongs to Ellie and London and girls who have decided not to let men keep all the tics.

Elliot declared himself ready to take on his own lies with a swagger that would have broken my heart if I had that many spares. He told me he had pinched an answer from a forum for his physics paper and then had spent two days with his chest heavy because it turned out the wrong answer had been the braver one. He wanted me to absolve him with Latin and I refused. Instead, I made him write the answer he would have written if he had believed he could stand the long way round. We stuck it to the fridge with a magnet shaped like a tomato and he insisted on bringing the magnet home because shame dressed as humour is a jacket that fits teenage boys for three summers at least.

The lever by the bus station flowered into copies like dandelions. One appeared outside the Co-op with a laminated card that read pick up one thing that is not yours and a child asked if this meant stealing and an old man told him it meant a receipt with no numbers. Another handle went up by the small pitch near the riverside where men pretend their knees still secretively belong to them; it counted passes made instead of shots taken, and for one odd week you could hear the sound of men choosing to pass because they wanted to see the chalked number on the fence rise like a tide. Someone clever placed a handle in the foyer of the council offices with the label I listened before speaking and the first Monday two women nearly broke it off. I cheered privately in the way you cheer for a friend who has arrived at a habit you feared would never become their size.

It was about then that a sleek man with hair like a polished shoe wrote to say he had built an app that would save us from our own cloth. He called it KeepScore, which took my breath away for exactly the wrong reasons, and his email read like a manual for installing guilt on your phone. He proposed little badges for acts, points that would develop into tiers, leaderboards that would shame us into grace. He had a deck with graphs that wanted everyone to be a number and a mock-up of me smiling a smile that did not belong to my face under the words Founder’s Pick. I replied with an honesty I hoped would sting without scarring; I told him that humiliation wears the same shirt on weekends as on weekdays and that an app cannot count the thing it thinks it counts. I said he should build a tool that remembers to forget and pays in ribbons that rot. He wrote back to tell me that I had failed to understand network effects. He was not wrong, he was only late. A week later a woman from the same firm wrote to say they were pivoting to a B2B kindness solution, which was as sad as it was inevitable.

We lost the owl for three days and told ourselves not to be superstitious. Rafe attributed it to the heat and the hunt and the fact of creatures having their own schedules; Lee said someone would have shot it for looking at them like a better man. The keep felt nervous without that soft surveillance. We went about our early rituals with the extra politeness people adopt in a house where the host has stepped out for bread and left you with a table you do not know well enough to lean on. On the second evening of absence Rafe sat with his back to the north wall and told me stories about uncles who point at clouds and make plans, and I told him the story of the time I had tried to swim at Mersea as a young man and found that the sea has a way of measuring you that is ungenerous but fair. On the third morning the bird returned the way an aunt returns: late, with a fish in her mouth and no apology. It stared at us as if we were the ones who had been missing. We groaned aloud and then pretended we had not, in case the foreman heard us and decided we were sentimental men who should not be allowed on ladders.

I had dreamed of rivers in the heat and woke with salt on my tongue that had not come from sleep. The sea at West Mersea is a shrug of a sea. It does not fling itself, it persuades. I asked Rafe to come with me and to bring the cloth and a length of rope and he did not ask me why, which made me love him for a new reason. We went at nine in the morning to avoid the heat pretending to be virtue and stood by the water’s edge where children learn a lifelong caution of brown water and parents learn the choreography of towels. I stepped in with the rope looped twice around my wrist and the cloth in my hand like a flag of surrender and discovered that the sea, for all its indifference to my trousers, wanted me more than the wood had wanted me. The cold was late but truthful. When the water reached my knees I felt the lever of the rope and the weight of it and thought, briefly, that I had become an argument between shore and tide. Rafe stood with his boots in the foam and kept his eyes on the horizon like a man pretending at captaining. “Do not be poetic in there,” he said, which made me laugh, and the laughter reached him across the flattened distance as a small tug he acknowledged with two fingers against the rope. After, I dry-shivered in the car like a dog with a better vocabulary and he made fun of me for five minutes and then stopped when he realized that my hands had found their way back to this. It was not a cure because cures are for illnesses that can be removed like shoes, but it was a stitch, and stitches are what keep.

Nadia came in a taxi that smelled like newness and confided immediately, in the doorway as if the hallway were a priest, that her father had lapsed and then apologized in a sequence so predictable that writing it down would have felt like plagiarism. “I came to see if the ribbon thing was a trick,” she said, and I told her it was and that it worked anyway. We went to Blackmere with a strip of cloth she had cut from a pillowcase the day she decided to keep the pillow and not the excuses. She held the fabric as if it were trying to tell her a joke that only became funny at the end. She tied it low and tight in a knot that meant business, and when she stepped back her face did not change but her shoulders moved as if someone had set down a small bag of something heavy at her feet. “I thought I’d feel ridiculous,” she admitted. “I do. It helps.” We sat on the lower stone where men have sat to decide whether to fight for longer than any council remembers, and she told me about the way forgiveness feels like exercise when you start too late, how your lungs complain and your thighs hum. “I didn’t know I had a muscle there,” she said, and I told her that nobody does until they lift something with it. She snorted and said, “You really are a grammar clown,” and then she cried in the way of righteous women: neatly, with loyalty to herself.

At the siege house the bag had become a certainty, and a new ritual arrived uninvited but correct. When West Ham lost, Lee rang the little handbell his son had bought on the internet and whoever was nearest shouted “downstairs” once like a service call and the room let the man in question vanish without judgement. The bell’s tone learned the acoustics. No glass broke. The cleaner came in the mornings and wiped the thin drift of dust off the handle of the cellar door as if she were polishing a medal.

The council’s handles had begun to grow stickers, which is the local version of tattoos. By the third week of heat someone had written on the Queen Street lever in block capitals PULL PROPER and someone else had added in a different hand FOR YOURSELF and a third hand had added AND FOR THE ONE BEHIND. I watched three teenagers turn this into choreography, a sequence of touches with louder and softer pulls, and behind them a woman pulled with her elbow while holding a baby and the baby watched with the sort of seriousness babies reserve for rituals they intend to reinvent later and sell to us with a logo.

Letters arrived as if paper had been told that summer was going out of fashion. One was from a man who said he had built park benches that encouraged people to sit at diagonals to each other on purpose, so conversation could be graded from confrontation to confession using only feet. Another was from a woman who asked whether it was a cheat to forgive her sister only via the third person; she had decided to speak to the niece and let the aunt stand outside and she wanted to know if that was a peace or a cowardice. I told her that cowardice has an honest job sometimes and that peace is not a single door; it is a corridor with good signage and places to wait.

I had begun to think about the chapter in my head that would have to be about forgetting. The danger of ritual is residue. It builds up like limescale. The chalkboards can become a museum of good men and therefore a bad place to be an average one. I wanted a day a month when we wiped everything not because we were embarrassed but because we are finite and need space for fresh clumsy generosity. I proposed Forgetting Friday to the council woman with the scarf and she wrote back to say that someone in City Hall had suggested it already in a different accent. “We learn the same songs at different times,” she wrote, and then added, “You get to choose the biscuits,” which is the sort of delegated authority that makes a Brit feel seen.

A fire came and went like a boy showing off scars. The field grass baked to tinder and a handful of righteous idiots lit a corner of it and filmed the flames as if they had been the architects. It ran toward the outer wall and reached the ribbons with the hunger that heat has for symbolism, and the cloth blackened and waved its death like a flag of country you do not wish to invade. Someone called the fire brigade and they arrived with the bored competence of men and women who prefer to be wrong about urgency. It was out in ten minutes and smoke lay low and queried our throats and we coughed apologies to each other for reasons that were not entirely smoke. Rafe stood with his hands on his hips and made a sound like a kettle between states. He did not swear, which is how I knew he was furious. Afterwards he gathered the ashes of three ribbons and carried them in his palm like a naughty sacrament and put them in the brazier with our listening paper and said, “There. We have burned grief with grief. That is lighter.”

The foreman taught me to hold a length of steel like a friend you have to guide across ice. It is not delicate. It pretends to be simplicity itself. But it will bite you if you do not respect the leverage and he wanted me to see how the new braces would speak to the old stone. We worked in that slow heat that makes men say the same thing twice to confirm they are still the men who say it. He confided, apropos of nothing and the weather, that he had once fallen in love with a viaduct and that his wife had been patient about this. “You cannot cheat gravity; you can only persuade it to behave in company,” he said, and I nearly asked him to deliver my next talk.

Ellie turned up on a Friday with a bag that sighed and a face that contained a London week. She stood in my doorway and we watched each other enact our small ritual of not touching and then she declared herself too hot to be precious and we invented a new variant: a bump of knuckles through the cloth as if we were two boxers with a gentleman’s agreement not to make a fight of it. She brought me a market ribbon of a ridiculous length, silk the colour of the Circle line if someone had washed it with a white shirt by mistake, and we wound it twice and then twice again across the inner arch until it made a horizon. “It looks like someone has underlined the keep,” she said, and then laughed at herself because she had made a pun without intending to. She told me about the upside-down mug ritual, which had infected another office and angered three managers and been defended by a cleaner with the line, “We are not machines to be switched on by a programmer,” and if I could have kissed that cleaner’s forehead from our town, I would have done it and sent her a biscuit in the post.

I suffered a moment on a Tuesday that I did not deserve and will remember longer than is dignified. I was on the Roman wall near the place where it lifts to look across at the park and a dog with the manners of a prince trotted by, and as it passed me it altered its step with the sort of adjustment animals make for the elderly and the broken. It made room for me in the air. It had not learned that from an app or a council pilot; it had learned by being a creature among other creatures. The man with the lead called an apology I did not need and I nodded and thought, treacherously, that if a dog can do this without a ribbon then perhaps everything I have written is one long caption to something obvious. Afterwards I wrote a page in which the word obvious appears nine times and then struck six and left three because humility is a muscle and I was already tired.

Lee’s boy came one evening to the ribbons with a friend whose mouth did not know what to do with vulnerability. They stood at the entry with their bicycles placed like barriers and tried their jokes and tried their indifference and then, when they found neither moved me, they climbed and tied nothing and left, and twenty minutes later one of them returned alone with a piece of a T-shirt and tied it in a place that would not be seen by anyone who did not crouch. He looked at me with his face as if asking permission to be what he had just been and I nodded the nod adults give when they are practicing not interfering with the tender. He left without swagger and that felt like a victory worth more than a tune.

The Council sent a woman from communications who wanted to know if we would accept a plaque. Plaques are the state’s attempt to decide which pieces of time should survive. She had a file full of fonts and a question about whether we wanted the mayor to bring scissors. Rafe looked at her as if she had asked him whether he kept pets. “No plaque,” he said gently. “If we have to nail a sentence to the wall to make it real, we have failed. If you must, put a hook and let people hang their own words and take them away again.” To her credit she bothered to look relieved instead of annoyed at the failure of her stock solution. She showed us a draft anyway because professionals must, and in the draft was the word community twice and I asked her to cross one out and she did it with a pencil as if I had given her permission to wear her shoes to a party.

At the house the fridge finally misbehaved in a way that made even my patience consider eloping. It died, theatrically, with the whirr of a man pretending to faint, and I stood in the kitchen and realized that I could smell the freon’s ghost and that it was the first smell to arrive as smell without wager in a week. I forgave the appliance its collapse and texted Lee to borrow his van and went to the shop and bought a new machine that had quieter ambitions. The delivery man asked me to sign a thing on a screen and when I held the stylus it surprised me by resisting at the correct moment and I found myself thanking him twice in a tone that must have made him suspect I had been released that morning from some difficult arrangement. He asked for water and I poured it and we practised a ritual of drinking that involved my side of the cloth and his side of politeness and he left and I was so stupidly happy about the dignity of the exchange that I nearly wept. This is how peace makes a fool of a man if he has been wrestled by the everyday for too long.

I wrote to the headmaster in Glasgow with three questions and he replied to all of them with a story. One about a girl who had stopped biting because the school had given her an honest job that involved scissors; one about a teacher who had asked for a chair outside his class for when he had to not shout and the chair had become a holy thing without being called that; one about a swing chained high for winter that a boy had unchained for a girl with a broken arm without permission and had been praised publicly in a way that did not feel like a punishment. I wanted to put these stories under glass and take them around with me so that when men with crisp hair asked me to license the idea I could show them that the idea had already refused to sit on their lap.

By the time the heat broke, the town smelt like wet rope and gratitude. Rain arrived with no symmetry and made puddles where a week ago there had been dust and a sense of inevitability. Children went out as if born anew into a country that had decided to be generous. The gull closed his beak and shook his feathers to let us know he had survived. I went to the keep without a jacket and found the ribbon Ellie had tied quivering like a violin string at the end of a long note and thought of all the things in this town held by small tensions: our patience, our kindness, our roofs, our ligaments, our faith in the handle by the bus station. I stood there with the cloth in my pocket and my hand on the stone and felt, honestly and without theatre, the cold through the pads of my fingers. I cheered for the stone quietly, like men do when their team scores at five past midnight and the baby next door is sleeping.

Then, because the world will have its drama whether you schedule it or not, Ellie’s father died on a Tuesday and London expected her to be back at her desk on Thursday and she came down on Wednesday instead and we sat in my kitchen and did not drink tea for half an hour. Grief arrived in her like a quiet colleague with a clipboard and did its audit without humour. She lay her head on the table and said, “I did most of it already,” and that, I understood, was not a boast but a record of rituals that had kept her upright for two years while the man faded. We went to Blackmere because even the slow patient death of a father wants a place where you can perform the dignity of being small. She tied a strip of his shirt in a knot so clean the boy with the hoodie would have admired it. She said nothing and the owl made the vowel of agreement. Rafe came and put the cloth over our hands and we shook it once, a proof of friendship that did not require skin or speech. There are days when rituals leave the church and live in the fields. We had made a field for that.

A week later I received a letter from a solicitor with the tone of an aunt informing you that your great-uncle had left you a piano in a house three counties away. It turned out my grandfather, who had lived his life as if cigarette smoke were a sacrament, had named me in a will that had taken six years to untangle. The sum was not significant, except to me. It was enough to fix a section of wall without asking for permission. It was enough to buy a hundred cloths and leave them hanging from the doorframes of men who cannot be touched. It was enough to take three of my students to the sea to teach them to be persuaded instead of won. I sat with the letter and put it under the clock and said my grandfather’s name aloud for the first time in a year and discovered, with pleasure, that the room made space in its sound for him. I told Rafe and he laughed and said, “We are always being paid by men we only half forgive. Bring the cheques to the foreman like penitent thieves,” and I promised I would.

I began to make myself a new list of tokens. We had apology, we had mended, we had waited. I added returned, left alone, held back, wiped clean. I made one that said forgot and wrote underneath it in a smaller hand on purpose did not keep score, and at the end of the week I slid that one in under the corner of the bus-station handle and watched an old woman lift it like a transparent cup and smile as if I had handed her a recipe her grandmother had made with poor flour and laughter. The lever creaked in the proper place. The rain walked by like an old friend who likes to be noticed and hates to be praised. The wall kept its rhythm; I stepped old, new, old, new, and did not think of ghosts as much as I thought of knees.

Nights, when heat and rain had gone to their rooms to be opinionated in private, I lay and drew in my head a plan for a small handbook that would refuse to be a manual. I called it, in my sleep, The Quiet Agreement in Practice, then struck through the title and wrote Keeping without Heroes. It would contain no diagrams a venture capital firm could understand. It would be a list of ridiculous things you could do and know without needing an app: tie cloth; ring a bell; build a handle; put chalk where water cannot reach; design a sandbox to be closed with ceremony; fix a bag to a beam with two nails; decide, publicly, the day you will forget; write tokens that reward waiting instead of wanting. At the back it would have a page in which the only instruction would be ask your dog. I laughed in the dark at my own arrogance and then stopped laughing because my laughter had sounded like relief. The gull on the pole made a sound at a reasonable hour and the day followed the sound into the room like a well-trained animal. I got up and wrote the date, and the pen squeaked, and it was the best squeak I had heard all summer.Chapter 10 begins with the feeling of weather remembering its manners. Autumn arrived as if summoned by an apology, stepping down onto the pavements in a way that made the leaves pretend they had always intended to fall in that pattern. The Roman wall regained its temper; it had suffered summer like an old soldier tolerates a parade. The gull on the pole arranged his feathers into a waistcoat and resumed looking as if winter were something he was prepared to negotiate. The air tasted of pears that had gotten there on their own, which is to say the sweetness was an accident you could forgive. In my rooms the fridge behaved, the whiteboard marker surrendered its ink without me having to coax it, and my hand on the wooden banister reported back with confidence that wood was still wood and not simply the idea of itself. If I am honest, the first true cold I felt through my fingers in September made me clench and then loosen like a man letting go of a rope he has been holding too long; relief and a little shame travel together.

Schools rediscovered us as if we had been misfiled under castles instead of under keeps. Children came up the path to Blackmere in crocodiles, their coats zipped to the throat by mothers who know what hedges can do to a jumper, and teachers who had prepared three facts and a joke asked Rafe if the owl had a name. He told them it did not, because naming turns a creature into a thing you can threaten with ownership, and the woman in charge of the trip looked pleased to be learning something she could carry back and pretend she had known all along. I taught my first lesson at the keep to a class of eleven-year-olds who had that specialised scorn for adults who stray into metaphor too early and then get trapped there. We did not talk about ritual, we talked about games. I gave them ribbon and string and told them to invent a rule that would make it possible for six people to go up the stairs in peace and come back down without crying, and they did it in three minutes flat: two up, two wait, two down, shout your number as you turn, turn left at the landing because turning right is unlucky. The boy who had been determined to become an accident when he arrived invented the best part: if you bump someone, you have to tell them one hope you have for them by the time you reach the next step. They looked at me then, as children do when they have taught you your own job, and I applauded with a seriousness that acknowledged the wisdom without turning it into a photograph.

People wrote to me with their own keeps and their own deralictions. A woman in Norwich had started tying bread-bag ties to a lamppost in colours that meant nothing until they did, and now three men in their sixties stopped there on their way to the shop and retied, each, the one that had come undone overnight. A man in Leeds—my old pessimist by proxy—sent me an image of a handle he had attached to the inside of his front door for pressing on days when the knocking was in his head, not on the wood. He had written above it, in a hand that had learned steadiness very late, PRESS IF YOU HEAR IT AND DO NOTHING ELSE YET, and I found myself breathing out as if someone had shown me the diagram I had been missing. We were all, it seemed, inventing our own third things for the old problems, and I did not know how to be grand about it without becoming silly, so I let myself be small and grateful and comprehensive of detail. I filed every picture. I refused to keep anyone’s name.

Of course the country noticed in the way countries notice: a column with humour like a long finger wagged itself in our direction. The writer, who wore his cleverness like a coat he had outgrown, called our ribbons twee and our handles a fetish for the obvious, and suggested that peace, if it was to have any dignity at all, should be negotiated between large men at tables with invisible cloth. He called me the Keeper of the Nothing Much. I ought to have ignored it because he was only doing his job at his own altar, but pride got into my teeth the way spinach does and I had to floss it out. Lee read it in the Siege House and shut the paper with a flat palm and said, "He’s the sort of bloke who thinks kindness is a queue you’re trying to skip," which is a better argument than any I could write. Nadia texted to say she had bought herself a cake and written the columnist’s name on it in icing and then eaten the letter that began his name first, and I forgave our press entirely on the strength of that sentence.

KeepScore sent a link to a prototype, hoping I would be tempted by the particles of power their charts promised me. The app had a page called Boards where you could watch numbers climb like ivy, and a page called Legends where people who had pressed handles more times than their neighbours were photographed standing awkwardly beside objects they had once put away. I took a breath that wanted to be anger and made it into a letter instead. I told them I would meet them at the bus-station handle at noon on Friday and we would watch for ten minutes without filming. They arrived with hair and matching voices and stood with their phones in their hands like men who have always known where to put their hands in a crisis and have never been told it is not a crisis yet. We watched an old woman pull with her elbow and a small boy pull with his whole body and a teenager tap the handle twice as if asking it to accept an apology on his behalf, and after five minutes one of the app-men put his phone away. He said, quietly, with the decency that sometimes arrives in a man like an old school tie he wears again at a funeral, "There’s no leaderboard for this," and the other one said, "We could do badges that fade," and I, against my own better pose of being beyond persuasion, said, "If they must, let them rot with use." They went away and I allowed myself the sin of hope for men with hair like that.

Rafe’s father’s news came on a cool Tuesday when the light in the lane decided to be private. The old man who had taught us not to step on old stones and new with the same foot had begun to become much less of a man very quickly, and the apprentice grief that walks into a room before the family does took its seat on my mantel without offering to make tea. Rafe called from a hospital corridor that smelled of humility and hand gel and told me his father had asked if the keep was still standing and, when told yes, had said the phrase that makes sons become men whether they are ready or not: "Good. Keep it." He laughed when he told me that, the small laugh that men use when their tongues are not big enough to hold the size of what they have been given to say. He did not ask me to come. I went. We sat together in the car outside the entrance where ambulances stage their elaborate ballet and did not perform either of our practised rituals. I held the cloth in a way that did not offer anything and he rested his hand on it as if he were pinning a map. The nurse with the patience of a harbour told us to go home and sleep and we did not. We went to Blackmere and tied a strip of his father’s flannel at knee height where only children and dogs would see it and the owl made that sound it keeps for ceremonies that men invent and does not mock us for.

The funeral had the correct weather. England has a way of arranging itself for grief as if it had been bred for this purpose. The rain held itself back like a child learning to wait its turn. The church decided to smell like itself in case any of us had forgotten how to behave. I stood at the back with the cloth folded to the size of a man’s palm and watched Rafe carry what was left of his father as if the old man were a beam that would span two gaps if only we could find the correct angle. There is a moment in every burial when the idea of earth and the idea of flesh agree to be friends for a second; I was asked to take a spade and throw soil and the cloth made a hinge that let me hold the wood tight enough to do it without turning the gesture into a play put on for the living. Afterwards, in the pub that had learned to pour beer with extra gravity on days like that, a man with a long history of knowing Rafe clapped him on the shoulder and then looked at his hand as if it had misbehaved. Rafe said, without being asked to be brave, "He made me step old then new and now I will do it until my knees forgive neither of us," and I thought how much easier it is to keep a promise to a dead man than to anyone still capable of changing their mind.

Ellie came for the wake and stood by the radiator with a plate of triangular sandwiches that behaved as if they had never met a tomato before. She had that look city people get when they are asked to be rural for an afternoon and discover they have been rural all along. She did not attempt to hug; we enacted our ritual of knuckles and cloth and then amended it without speaking because grief has a way of demanding an upgrade. She stood beside me while I fumbled small talk into meaning and we performed a good old English miracle: we held a conversation entirely out of the weather and the quality of the sausage rolls and came out the other side understanding that the thing we did not say had been said. Later she came to Blackmere and tied a strip of ribbon the colour of the line that carries her to the station and whispered something I pretended I did not hear. I have learned this much from keeping: privacy is not secrecy; it is a ritual you do on behalf of the other person’s future.

The boy with the hoodie stopped being only a boy with a hoodie when his friend was arrested for something so dull it hurt—shoplifting beer—and the boys with louder coats tried to fold him into a new story that would have kept him busy for years with nothing to show for it. Lee’s son brought him up to the keep on a Wednesday like a man bringing a stray to a vet and left him with us for an hour. We gave him a piece of steel to hold. The foreman has a way with boys who are trying warily to be men; he does not flatter, he does not jolly, he gives you a weight and asks you to move it and then praises the angle rather than the effort. The boy took to the work as if someone had finally given him an honest verb. At the end he did not smile—he had not learned the ritual of smiling at a man—but he came back on Friday and brought a strip of T-shirt with the name of a band no one over twenty remembers and tied it high, as if he had decided to work for a vantage point.

The first cold bit properly and the bus-station handle made a sound like gratitude. The Council, as councils do when they are feeling hopeful and have not yet been contradicted by the budget, declared a Month of Keeping and produced a poster with a hand-drawn hand that was almost insulting and the right amount of silly. We refused a ceremony and invented three small ones that could be done without an audience. On Wednesdays we wrote the number of apologies we owed on tiny scraps and put them in our own pockets and left them there until Friday, when we took them out and crossed out the ones we could and burned the rest under a kettle so the steam could carry the idea of repair round the kitchen. On Sundays we walked the wall and if we saw someone coming towards us we shifted our rhythm so we would not meet on old and new at the same time because, for the month at least, all of us accepted the superstition as a way of taking part. On the last day we wiped the chalkboards in three places at once: the bus station, the little pitch by the river, the council foyer, and the sound of numbers becoming dust felt like a cathedral has been opened and all the air had gone out to be rain for a while.

Somewhere in the middle of all this I began the handwork of the handbook. I called it Keeping without Heroes the way a man names a dog with a name he hopes will improve his nature. Nadia became my editor by accident; she sent me paragraphs of her father’s new rituals and I stole their bones for a chapter called Meaningful Laziness, and she did not mind because she has learned that the point of a ritual is not to keep the credit but to keep the habit. The headmaster in Glasgow sent me a list of furniture that had saved his teachers from shouting and I folded it into a section called Geography of Forgiveness. Lee contributed a page without knowing he had, about the bell and the bag and the difference between loudness and fury, and I wrote around it with reverence disguised as anecdotes in order not to embarrass a man who had given me a sentence like “We are not trying to win, we are trying not to lose our afternoons.” Ellie proofread and corrected my fondness for semicolons, which she called my love affairs with pauses, and drew a little cat beside every paragraph she suspected of trying to be lovely instead of useful. Rafe refused to read any of it. He told me, warmly and with a kindness I have rarely been given so directly, that he would hold the wall and I should hold the pages and if either of us turned up to the other’s job the keep would start to sulk.

The first frost made patterns on the inner face of the north wall that looked like someone had pressed their breath against it and forgotten to come back. Breath is a ritual too; I had forgotten this. I practiced not just the cloth and the handle, but breathing as if I had a rhythm to keep in step with other people. I counted in fours when I was tired and in sixes when I wanted to be clever and in sevens when I wanted to remind myself that not all patterns should be comfortable. The body is obedient if you treat it with the kind of affection you reserve for a cat. It will not perform on demand, but if you make the room the correct temperature and pretend not to be watching, it comes and sits on your lap and forgives you for having been human all day.

Trouble arrived, as it always does, on a night when a small victory had made us soft. Teens with boredom dressed as mischief climbed the scaffold because steel is a dare, and one of them slipped because gravity is impatient with us when we pretend to be exceptions. He fell well, which is a sentence you can only write about the young and the lucky. He caught the lower bar with a forearm and hung there with a noise he will never pretend he did not make. The other boys froze because freezing is what fiction teaches us to do. Rafe moved as if he had rehearsed this in his sleep and I was half a beat behind him with the stupid cloth, which in that moment was not silly at all. We stretched it between us and under the boy and told him to let go in a tone grown men reserve for babies and brakes. He did. His weight arrived through the cloth and through our arms and into the ground with the kind of truth that leaves its autograph on your shoulders. He sat on the stone afterwards and said "sorry" seven times with different nouns, which is as good as any ritual in the circumstances. We did not give him a lecture because lectures are for mornings. We made him tea that tasted like a reprieve and he left his laces tied to the lowest rung as if he had understood something he did not want to translate. The next day I wrote a line in the handbook that embarrassed me later when I read it aloud but kept it anyway: In a town that keeps, even gravity’s scolding can be made into a group activity.

A letter arrived without a return address, a real one with fibre in the paper and a stamp someone had licked without swearing. Inside was a drawing in a child’s hand of a handle like ours and a ribbon like ours and a dog that looked like music and the word THANK in the wrong place, and I pinned it to the board with a magnet shaped like a tomato and did not move it for weeks. Under it I began to draft the last chapter, the one that would have to give instructions for the only part of the Quiet Agreement that frightened me: how to leave. Not the town; the rituals. Not permanently; the days when everything wants to become a mania or a brand and you need to stand in your own kitchen and declare an amnesty. I wrote in plain words because plain words are kinder when you are tired. If you have tied too many ribbons, untie one and throw it in a drawer for a week. If you have pressed too many handles, go and watch someone else press and keep your hands in your pockets. If you have been the bell in the basement for too long, teach someone else to hold the rope and sit upstairs and let the sound do the work without looking for your face in it. If you have become the man who always has a cloth, put it in the wash and let it be a napkin for a while. I wrote, in a sentence I would later pretend to be embarrassed by so people would forgive me: Keeping is only clean if someone somewhere is allowed to make a mess.

It is a vanity to pretend that I did not enjoy the parcels that arrived addressed only to The Keeper. They were mostly paper and cloth and the occasional hand bell and once a pair of nails taped to a card that said “for bracing” in a handwriting that made the r look like a fish. One parcel was a small wooden lever made by someone with gentle thumbs and the words PULL WHEN YOU FORGET WHO YOU ARE carved into it with a knife that had seen better wood. I went with Lee and we fixed it to the inner face of the Siege House cellar door not because it would help anyone but because it made us feel like men you could rely on to put a thing where things should go. The ritual of being useful to someone else’s room is the closest I have come to worship.

The winter holiday approached in its usual woolly hat, and houses in our street did their display of electricity with a competitiveness that was all apology and no sarcasm. The Council, in a fit of courage, put no decorations on the lever and placed a small sign beside it that read simply CONTINUE. Ellie sent a message from London that she would be coming down to breathe where the air was pedestrian again and to make the keep into a place you could carry in your pocket when the offices tried to sell you gold foil as a personality. She asked if I would mind if she brought a friend who wanted, her words, to see the ridiculous. I wrote back to say that we have built for ridicule and that it is welcome as long as it brings its own thermos.

Rafe and I took the cloth and went to the wall one night when frost had got into the grammar of the pavements and corrected them. We kept his father’s rhythm more carefully for a bit, not because we believed but because belief is a muscle too and you should exercise it in company sometimes. The town made the sound it makes when people are writing cards without meaning to and waiting in lines without murdering each other and making promises in shops with the intention of keeping at least half of them. The keep, when we reached it, accepted us without ceremony, which is my favourite way to be accepted by anything. We stood beneath the arch and looked at the ribbons that had decided to become weather on our behalf and we spoke about nothing until we were finally able to speak about what we meant. He said he did not know if he was built for a decade of keeping. I said no one is until they have done the first year twice. He said that if he ever began to feel brave he hoped I would tell him to sit down for a bit. I promised I would. We shook the cloth once, a stupid little flag of our own, and went home to our kettles and our fridges and our beds which, that night, believed us a little more than usual.

You will ask, because you have learned my habits, how my body behaved while all this was going on. It behaved like a country that has decided to stay in the union and also to keep its own currency. It negotiated. It found me the floor most days and forgave me the ones when the chair had to do. The cloth became an accessory rather than a necessity for whole afternoons and then resumed its former glory without drama when the morning’s heroism turned to a puddle at three. The dog with the manners adopted me for a week and then forgot me politely. The boy in the hoodie taught me a greeting that involves chin and forearm and gives no one the opportunity to misread anyone. The gull acknowledged Christmas by looking for chips with more charity than usual.

On the last day of the year, when men take stock and women remember where the jars are and children decide whether to ask before they open the last present, I stood at the bus-station handle and pulled it once with a care that would have made the columnists furious. I watched the chalk through the glass show the new number and felt nothing noble and everything necessary. A woman with a scarf like a brave flag stood beside me and did the same and we nodded as if we had agreed to be married to the town for another year with no priest to turn the nod into a legal fiction. I went home and laid the first printed copies of Keeping without Heroes on the table and placed the cloth on top as if paper needed a blessing. I did not write my name on the spine. I left space where the authors usually go and drew, in pencil that can be erased, a small square that looks like a handle and a smaller square beneath it for anyone to press. I went to bed before midnight like a man who has learned that the newness of a year is a poor instrument, and at some hour when men who have decided to be boys again were shouting at the sky, I woke to the owl making its vowel with more confidence than usual, as if even it had to celebrate something sometimes, and I smiled into the dark until my face gave in and became sleep.

message.content:
Colchester has a way of swallowing you. The Roman wall curls through the town like the rind of a fruit someone gnawed at and left on a plate, and if you walk its line twice in one day you start to feel the same jagged curve inside your head. I taught Latin and mathematics to teenagers in a terraced house off Magdalen Street, three afternoons a week and then as many evenings as I could stomach. The house was narrow, the ceiling flaked in corners, and the rain when it came drummed not on roof tiles but on the idea of roof tiles, a drum with the skin pulled too tight.

On Monday mornings the buses hissed past my window and a gull had taken to sitting on the telephone pole across the road. He kept one eye on me and the other on whatever gulls watch. He knew the schedule better than I did. He could sense bread, or failure, from streets away.

My name is Milo Seton. I have never liked the sound of it, but I imagine few of us do. A name is something given to you and then invited to stay the night for years on end. A tutor is something I chose to be because I was not strong enough to be anything else; you can hide behind the language of syllabi, the safety of markers and mocks, behind phrases like it depends and show your working. Students come to you with their fog and you make a show of living with it.

I was writing on the whiteboard with a blue pen that had run faint when the first hint of what I called later the Quiet Agreement came to me. Not a revelation, nothing with lightning. Something more like when a tight shirt finally gives at the seam.

Elliot, sixteen and scowling with his fringe over his eyes, was halfway through telling me that no one would ever use Latin in real life because it was dead, sir. It’s deader than dead. You're wasting your time, mate. He liked to call me mate when he wanted to be cruel and felt too young to be allowed. He’d brought in a packet of crisps and the smell of salt and vinegar caught in my throat.

"You will use it today," I said. Stupid reply. Teacherish. "Caveat emptor. When you buy your new trainers online and the picture lies to you. Caveat emptor, Elliot."

"I’m not buying anything," he said, which made no sense because I could see the tab open on his phone where he was trying to decide between two colours of shoes.

I drew, under the conjugation of amo, amas, amat, a crooked circle with four arrows inwards. "Pretend," I said, "that you and three others share a park. If you litter, the park becomes ugly. If you don't, the park stays clean. If the other three litter, your effort keeps only a quarter clean, but the others enjoy their laziness. So what happens?"

He rolled his eyes. "They litter."

"And you?"

He shrugged. "Depends what I feel like."

"There it is," I said, surprising myself at the way my finger tapped the whiteboard as if the board were a table and we were in a café in Rome. "There’s the whole of it. The shape of the bad decision. If every person chooses my benefit now over our benefit later, the park becomes a bin. But if each of us can be convinced—or compelled—to act for our benefit later at small cost now, then we win together. The trick has to be—"
